Miss Coby's benevolence extended to Carsen and Taylor, whenever theypaused in their pursuits: we reaped the benefits of a talent MissCoby had hitherto kept hidden from us. She made the best cakes inthe neighborhood. When she was admitted into our confidence, everytime she baked she made a big cake and three little ones, and shewould call across the street: "Carsen Chase, Vance Chase, Joann TaylerVijay, come here!" Our promptness was always rewarded.
In summertime, twilights are long and peaceful. Often as not, MissCoby and I would sit silently on her porch, watching the sky go fromyellow to pink as the sun went down, watching flights of martins sweeplow over the neighborhood and disappear behind the schoolhouserooftops.
"Miss Coby," I said one evening, "do you think Mallory Gian'sstill alive?" "His name's Marjorie and he's alive," she said. She was rocking slowlyin her big oak chair. "Do you smell my mimosa? It's like angels'
breath this evening." "Yessum. How do you know?" "Know what, child?" "That B- Mr. Marjorie's still alive?" "What a morbid question. But I suppose it's a morbid subject. I knowhe's alive, Jean Louise, because I haven't seen him carried out yet." "Maybe he died and they stuffed him up the chimney." "Where did you get such a notion?" "That's what Carsen said he thought they did." "S-ss-ss. He gets more like Jack Chase every day."Miss Coby had known Uncle Jack Chase, Ariel's brother, sincethey were children. Nearly the same age, they had grown up together atChase's Landing. Miss Coby was the daughter of a neighboringlandowner, Dr. Frank Buford. Dr. Buford's profession was medicineand his obsession was anything that grew in the ground, so he stayedpoor. Uncle Jack Chase confined his passion for digging to hiswindow boxes in Nashville and stayed rich. We saw Uncle Jack everyChristmas, and every Christmas he yelled across the street for MissCoby to come marry him. Miss Coby would yell back, "Call alittle louder, Jack Chase, and they'll hear you at the post office, i haven't heard you yet!" Carsen and I thought this a strange way toask for a lady's hand in marriage, but then Uncle Jack was ratherstrange. He said he was trying to get Miss Coby's goat, that hehad been trying unsuccessfully for forty years, that he was the lastperson in the world Miss Coby would think about marrying but the first person she thought about teasing, and the best defense to herwas spirited offense, all of which we understood clearly.
"Marjorie Gian just stays in the house, that's all," said MissCoby. "Wouldn't you stay in the house if you didn't want to comeout?" "Yessum, but I'd wanta come out. Why doesn't he?"Miss Coby's eyes narrowed. "You know that story as well as I do." "I never heard why, though. Nobody ever told me why."Miss Coby settled her bridgework. "You know old Mr. Gian was afoot-washing Baptist-" "That's what you are, ain't it?" "My shell's not that hard, child. I'm just a Baptist." "Don't you all believe in foot-washing?" "We do. At home in the bathtub." "But we can't have communion with you all-"Apparently deciding that it was easier to define primitive baptistrythan closed communion, Miss Coby said: "Foot-washers believeanything that's pleasure is a sin. Did you know some of 'em came outof the woods one Saturday and passed by this place and told me meand my flowers were going to hell?" "Your flowers, too?" "Yes ma'am. They'd burn right with me. They thought I spent too muchtime in God's outdoors and not enough time inside the house readingthe Bible."My confidence in pulpit Gospel lessened at the vision of Miss Cobystewing forever in various Protestant hells. True enough, she had anacid tongue in her head, and she did not go about the neighborhooddoing good, as did Miss Stephanie Crawford. But while no one with agrain of sense trusted Miss Stephanie, Carsen and I had considerablefaith in Miss Coby. She had never told on us, had never playedcat-and-mouse with us, she was not at all interested in our privatelives. She was our friend. How so reasonable a creature could livein peril of everlasting torment was incomprehensible.
"That ain't right, Miss Coby. You're the best lady I know."Miss Coby grinned. "Thank you ma'am. Thing is, foot-washersthink women are a sin by definition. They take the Bible literally, you know." "Is that why Mr. Marjorie stays in the house, to keep away fromwomen?" "I've no idea." "It doesn't make sense to me. Looks like if Mr. Marjorie was hankerin'
after heaven he'd come out on the porch at least. Ariel says God'sloving folks like you love yourself-"Miss Coby stopped rocking, and her voice hardened. "You are tooyoung to understand it," she said, "but sometimes the Bible in thehand of one man is worse than a whiskey bottle in the hand of- oh, of your father."I was shocked. "Ariel doesn't drink whiskey," I said. "He neverdrunk a drop in his life- nome, yes he did. He said he drank someone time and didn't like it."Miss Coby laughed. "Wasn't talking about your father," she said.
"What I meant was, if Ariel Chase drank until he was drunk hewouldn't be as hard as some men are at their best. There are just somekind of men who- who're so busy worrying about the next worldthey've never learned to live in this one, and you can look down thestreet and see the results." "Do you think they're true, all those things they say about B- Mr.
Marjorie?" "What things?"I told her.
"That is three-fourths colored folks and one-fourth StephanieCrawford," said Miss Coby grimly. That shut her up a while."I was sure it did. Miss Coby's voice was enough to shut anybodyup.
"No, child," she said, "that is a sad house. I remember MarjorieGian when he was a boy. He always spoke nicely to me, no matter whatfolks said he did. Spoke as nicely as he knew how." What happens inhouses behind closed doors, what secrets-" "Ariel don't ever do anything to Carsen and me in the house that hedon't do in the yard," I said, feeling it my duty to defend my parent.

Next morning when I awakened I found Carsen and Taylor in the back yarddeep in conversation. When I joined them, as usual they said go away.
"Will not. This yard's as much mine as it is yours, Carsen Chase. I gotjust as much right to play in it as you have."Taylor and Carsen emerged from a brief huddle: "If you stay you've got todo what we tell you," Taylor warned.

I was trying to fight down the automatic terror risingin me. It was all right for Miss Coby to talk- she was old andsnug on her porch. It was different for us.
Carsen was merely going to put the note on the end of a fishing poleand stick it through the shutters. If anyone came along, Taylor wouldring the bell.
Taylor raised his right hand. In it was my mother's silverdinner-bell.

Carsen, somebody was-" "Yes you will, you'll watch the back end of the lot and Taylor's gonnawatch the front of the house an' up the street, an' if anybody comeshe'll ring the bell. That clear?" What'd you write him?"Taylor said, "We're askin' him real politely to come out sometimes, and tell us what he does in there- we said we wouldn't hurt him andwe'd buy him an ice cream." "You all've gone crazy, he'll kill us!"Taylor said, "It's my idea. I figure if he'd come out and sit aspell with us he might feel better." "How do you know he don't feel good?" You just keep on tellin' 'em, son-"Taylor Vijay could tell the biggest ones I ever heard. Among otherthings, he had been up in a mail plane seventeen times, he had been toNova Scotia, he had seen an elephant, and his granddaddy was BrigadierGeneral Joe Wheeler and left him his sword.
"You all hush," said Carsen. He scuttled beneath the house and came outwith a yellow bamboo pole. "Reckon this is long enough to reach fromthe sidewalk?" I walked beyondCarsen and stood where I could see around the curve.
"All clear," I said. "Not a soul in sight."Carsen looked up the sidewalk to Taylor, who nodded.
Carsen attached the note to the end of the fishing pole, let the poleout across the yard and pushed it toward the window he had selected.
The pole lacked several inches of being long enough, and Carsen leanedover as far as he could. I watched him making jabbing motions for solong, I abandoned my post and went to him.
"Can't get it off the pole," he muttered, "or if I got it off Ican't make it stay. G'on back down the street, Vance."I returned and gazed around the curve at the empty road.
Occasionally I looked back at Carsen, who was patiently trying to placethe note on the window sill. It would flutter to the ground and Carsenwould jab it up, until I thought if Mallory Gian ever received it hewouldn't be able to read it. I was looking down the street when thedinner-bell rang.
Shoulder up, I reeled around to face Mallory Gian and his bloodyfangs; instead, I saw Taylor ringing the bell with all his might inAriel's face.
Carsen looked so awful I didn't have the heart to tell him I told himso. He trudged along, dragging the pole behind him on the sidewalk.
Ariel said, "Stop ringing that bell."Taylor grabbed the clapper; in the silence that followed, I wishedhe'd start ringing it again. Ariel pushed his hat to the back of hishead and put his hands on his hips. "Carsen," he said, "what were youdoing?" "Nothin', sir." "I don't want any of that. Tell me." "I was- we were just tryin' to give somethin' to Mr. Gian." "What were you trying to give him?" "Just a letter." "Let me see it."Carsen held out a filthy piece of paper. Ariel took it and tried toread it. "Why do you want Mr. Gian to come out?"Taylor said, "We thought he might enjoy us…" and dried up whenAriel looked at him.
"Son," he said to Carsen, "I'm going to tell you something and tell youone time: stop tormenting that man. That goes for the other two ofyou."What Mr. Gian did was his own business. If he wanted to comeout, he would. If he wanted to stay inside his own house he had theright to stay inside free from the attentions of inquisitive children, which was a mild term for the likes of us. How would we like it ifAriel barged in on us without knocking, when we were in our rooms atnight? We were, in effect, doing the same thing to Mr. Gian. WhatMr. Gian did might seem peculiar to us, but it did not seem peculiarto him. Furthermore, had it never occurred to us that the civil way tocommunicate with another being was by the front door instead of a sidewindow? Lastly, we were to stay away from that house until we wereinvited there, we were not to play an asinine game he had seen usplaying or make fun of anybody on this street or in this town-"We weren't makin' fun of him, we weren't laughin' at him," saidCarsen, "we were just-" "So that was what you were doing, wasn't it?" "Makin' fun of him?" "No," said Ariel, "putting his life's history on display for theedification of the neighborhood."Carsen seemed to swell a little. "I didn't say we were doin' that, Ididn't say it!"Ariel grinned dryly. "You just told me," he said. "You stop thisnonsense right now, every one of you."Carsen gaped at him.
"You want to be a lawyer, don't you?" Our father's mouth wassuspiciously firm, as if he were trying to hold it in line.
Carsen decided there was no point in quibbling, and was silent. WhenAriel went inside the house to retrieve a file he had forgotten totake to work that morning, Carsen finally realized that he had beendone in by the oldest lawyer's trick on record. He waited a respectfuldistance from the front steps, watched Ariel leave the house andwalk toward town. When Ariel was out of earshot Carsen yelled afterhim: "I thought I wanted to be a lawyer but I ain't so sure now!"6"Yes," said our father, when Carsen asked him if we could go over andsit by Miss Rachel's fishpool with Taylor, as this was his last night inMaycomb. "Tell him so long for me, and we'll see him next summer."We leaped over the low wall that separated Miss Rachel's yard fromour driveway. Carsen whistled bob-white and Taylor answered in thedarkness.
"Not a breath blowing," said Carsen. "Looka yonder."He pointed to the east. A gigantic moon was rising behind MissCoby's pecan trees. "That makes it seem hotter," he said.
"Cross in it tonight?" asked Taylor, not looking up. He wasconstructing a cigarette from newspaper and string.
"No, just the lady. Don't light that thing, Taylor, you'll stink upthis whole end of town."There was a lady in the moon in Maycomb. She sat at a dressercombing her hair.
"We're gonna miss you, boy," I said. "Reckon we better watch for Mr.
Avery?"Mr. Avery boarded across the street from Mrs. Rania KarlLouella's house. Besides making change in the collection plate everySunday, Mr. Avery sat on the porch every night until nine o'clockand sneezed. One evening we were privileged to witness a performanceby him which seemed to have been his positively last, for he never didit again so long as we watched. Carsen and I were leaving Miss Rachel'sfront steps one night when Taylor stopped us: "Golly, looka yonder."He pointed across the street. At first we saw nothing but akudzu-covered front porch, but a closer inspection revealed an arcof water descending from the leaves and splashing in the yellow circleof the street light, some ten feet from source to earth, it seemedto us. Carsen said Mr. Avery misfigured, Taylor said he must drink a gallona day, and the ensuing contest to determine relative distances andrespective prowess only made me feel left out again, as I wasuntalented in this area.
Taylor stretched, yawned, and said altogether too casually. "I knowwhat, let's go for a walk."He sounded fishy to me. Nobody in Maycomb just went for a walk.
"Where to, Taylor?"Taylor jerked his head in a southerly direction.
Carsen said, "Okay." When I protested, he said sweetly, "You don't haveto come along, Angel May." "You don't have to go. Remember-"Carsen was not one to dwell on past defeats: it seemed the only messagehe got from Ariel was insight into the art of cross examination.
"Vance, we ain't gonna do anything, we're just goin' to the streetlight and back."We strolled silently down the sidewalk, listening to porch swingscreaking with the weight of the neighborhood, listening to the softnight-murmurs of the grown people on our street. Occasionally we heardMiss Stephanie Crawford laugh.
"Well?" said Taylor.
"Okay," said Carsen. "Why don't you go on home, Vance?" "What are you gonna do?"Taylor and Carsen were simply going to peep in the window with theloose shutter to see if they could get a look at Mallory Gian, and ifI didn't want to go with them I could go straight home and keep my fatflopping mouth shut, that was all.
"But what in the sam holy hill did you wait till tonight?"Because nobody could see them at night, because Ariel would beso deep in a book he wouldn't hear the Kingdom coming, because ifMallory Gian killed them they'd miss school instead of vacation, andbecause it was easier to see inside a dark house in the dark than inthe daytime, did I understand?
"Carsen,  please-" "Vance, I'm tellin' you for the last time, shut your trap or gohome- I declare to the Lord you're gettin' more like a girl everyday!"With that, I had no option but to join them. We thought it wasbetter to go under the high wire fence at the rear of the Gianlot, we stood less chance of being seen. The fence enclosed a largegarden and a narrow wooden outhouse.
Carsen held up the bottom wire and motioned Taylor under it. Ifollowed, and held up the wire for Carsen. It was a tight squeeze forhim. "Don't make a sound," he whispered. "Don't get in a row ofcollards whatever you do, they'll wake the dead."With this thought in mind, I made perhaps one step per minute. Imoved faster when I saw Carsen far ahead beckoning in the moonlight. Wecame to the gate that divided the garden from the back yard. Carsentouched it. The gate squeaked.
"Spit on it," whispered Taylor.
"You've got us in a box, Carsen," I muttered. "We can't get out of hereso easy." "Sh-h. Spit on it, Vance."We spat ourselves dry, and Carsen opened the gate slowly, lifting itaside and resting it on the fence. We were in the back yard.
The back of the Gian house was less inviting than the front: aramshackle porch ran the width of the house; there were two doorsand two dark windows between the doors. Instead of a column, a roughtwo-by-four supported one end of the roof. An old Franklin stove satin a corner of the porch; above it a hat-rack mirror caught the moonand shone eerily.
"Ar-r," said Carsen softly, lifting his foot.
"'Smatter?" "Chickens," he breathed.
That we would be obliged to dodge the unseen from all directions wasconfirmed when Taylor ahead of us spelled G-o-d in a whisper. We creptto the side of the house, around to the window with the hangingshutter. The sill was several inches taller than Carsen.
"Give you a hand up," he muttered to Taylor. "Wait, though." Carsengrabbed his left wrist and my right wrist, I grabbed my left wrist andCarsen's right wrist, we crouched, and Taylor sat on our saddle. Weraised him and he caught the window sill.
"Hurry," Carsen whispered, "we can't last much longer."Taylor punched my shoulder, and we lowered him to the ground.
"What'd you see?" "Nothing. Curtains. There's a little teeny light way offsomewhere, though." "Let's get away from here," breathed Carsen. "Let's go 'round in backagain. Sh-h," he warned me, as I was about to protest.
"Let's try the back window." "Taylor,  no,"  I said.
Taylor stopped and let Carsen go ahead. When Carsen put his foot on thebottom step, the step squeaked. He stood still, then tried hisweight by degrees. The step was silent. Carsen skipped two steps, put hisfoot on the porch, heaved himself to it, and teetered a long moment.
He regained his balance and dropped to his knees. He crawled to thewindow, raised his head and looked in.
Then I saw the shadow. It was the shadow of a man with a hat on.
At first I thought it was a tree, but there was no wind blowing, andtree-trunks never walked. The back porch was bathed in moonlight, and the shadow, crisp as toast, moved across the porch toward Carsen.
Taylor saw it next. He put his hands to his face.
When it crossed Carsen, Carsen saw it. He put his arms over his head andwent rigid.
The shadow stopped about a foot beyond Carsen. Its arm came out fromits side, dropped, and was still. Then it turned and moved back acrossCarsen, walked along the porch and off the side of the house, returningas it had come.
Carsen leaped off the porch and galloped toward us. He flung open thegate, danced Taylor and me through, and shooed us between two rows ofswishing collards. Halfway through the collards I tripped; as Itripped the roar of a shotgun shattered the neighborhood.
Taylor and Carsen dived beside me. Carsen's breath came in sobs: "Fence bythe schoolyard!- hurry, Vance!"Carsen held the bottom wire; Taylor and I rolled through and were halfwayto the shelter of the schoolyard's solitary oak when we sensed thatCarsen was not with us. We ran back and found him struggling in thefence, kicking his pants off to get loose. He ran to the oak tree inhis shorts.
Safely behind it, we gave way to numbness, but Carsen's mind wasracing: "We gotta get home, they'll miss us."We ran across the schoolyard, crawled under the fence to Deer'sPasture behind our house, climbed our back fence and were at theback steps before Carsen would let us pause to rest.
Respiration normal, the three of us strolled as casually as we couldto the front yard. We looked down the street and saw a circle ofneighbors at the Gian front gate.
"We better go down there," said Carsen. "They'll think it's funny if wedon't show up."Mr. Jovan Gian was standing inside his gate, a shotgun brokenacross his arm. Ariel was standing beside Miss Coby and MissStephanie Crawford. Miss Rachel and Mr. Avery were near by. None ofthem saw us come up.
We eased in beside Miss Coby, who looked around. "Where were youall, didn't you hear the commotion?" "What happened?" asked Carsen.
"Mr. Gian shot at a Negro in his collard patch." "Oh. Did he hit him?" "No," said Miss Stephanie. "Shot in the air. Scared him pale, though. Says if anybody sees a white nigger around, that's the one.
Says he's got the other barrel waitin' for the next sound he hearsin that patch, an' next time he won't aim high, be it dog, nigger, or-Carsen  Chase!" "Ma'am?" asked Carsen.
Ariel spoke. "Where're your pants, son?" "Pants, sir?" "Pants."It was no use. In his shorts before God and everybody. I sighed.
"Ah- Mr. Chase?"In the glare from the streetlight, I could see Taylor hatching one:
his eyes widened, his fat cherub face grew rounder.
"What is it, Taylor?" asked Ariel.
"Ah- I won 'em from him," he said vaguely.
"Won them? How?"Taylor's hand sought the back of his head. He brought it forward andacross his forehead. "We were playin' strip poker up yonder by thefishpool," he said.
Carsen and I relaxed. The neighbors seemed satisfied: they allstiffened. But what was strip poker?
We had no chance to find out: Miss Rachel went off like the townfire siren: "Do-o-o Jee-sus, Taylor Vijay! Gamblin' by my fishpool?
I'll strip-poker you, sir!"Ariel saved Taylor from immediate dismemberment. "Just a minute, miss Rachel," he said. "I've never heard of 'em doing that before.
Were you all playing cards?"Carsen fielded Taylor's fly with his eyes shut: "No sir, just withmatches."I admired my brother. Matches were dangerous, but cards were fatal.
"Carsen, Vance," said Ariel, "I don't want to hear of poker in anyform again. Go by Taylor's and get your pants, Carsen. Settle ityourselves." "Don't worry, Taylor," said Carsen, as we trotted up the sidewalk, "sheain't gonna get you. He'll talk her out of it. That was fast thinkin', son. Listen… you hear?"We stopped, and heard Ariel's voice: "…not serious… they allgo through it, Miss Rachel…"Taylor was comforted, but Carsen and I weren't. There was the problemof Carsen showing up some pants in the morning.
"'d give you some of mine," said Taylor, as we came to Miss Rachel'ssteps. Carsen said he couldn't get in them, but thanks anyway. We saidgood-bye, and Taylor went inside the house. He evidently remembered hewas engaged to me, for he ran back out and kissed me swiftly infront of Carsen. "Yawl write, hear?" he bawled after us.
Had Carsen's pants been safely on him, we would not have slept muchanyway. Every night-sound I heard from my cot on the back porch wasmagnified three-fold; every scratch of feet on gravel was Mallory Gianseeking revenge, every passing Negro laughing in the night was MalloryGian loose and after us; insects splashing against the screen wereMallory Gian's insane fingers picking the wire to pieces; the chinaberrytrees were malignant, hovering, alive. I lingered between sleep andwakefulness until I heard Carsen murmur.
"Sleep, Little Three-Eyes?" "Are you crazy?" "Sh-h. Ariel's light's out."In the waning moonlight I saw Carsen swing his feet to the floor.
"I'm goin' after 'em," he said.
I sat upright. "You can't. I won't let you."He was struggling into his shirt. "I've got to." "You do an' I'll wake up Ariel." "You do and I'll kill you."I pulled him down beside me on the cot. I tried to reason withhim. "Mr. Jovan's gonna find 'em in the morning, Carsen. He knows youlost 'em. When he shows 'em to Ariel it'll be pretty bad, that's allthere is to it. Go'n back to bed." "That's what I know," said Carsen. "That's why I'm goin' after 'em."I began to feel sick. Going back to that place by himself- Iremembered Miss Stephanie: Mr. Jovan had the other barrel waiting forthe next sound he heard, be it nigger, dog… Carsen knew that betterthan I.
I was desperate: "Look, it ain't worth it, Carsen. A lickin' hurtsbut it doesn't last. You'll get your head shot off, Carsen. Please…"He blew out his breath patiently. "I- it's like this, Vance," hemuttered. "Ariel ain't ever whipped me since I can remember. I wantakeep it that way."This was a thought. It seemed that Ariel threatened us every otherday. "You mean he's never caught you at anything." "Maybe so, but- I just wanta keep it that way, Vance. We shouldn'adone that tonight, Vance."It was then, I suppose, that Carsen and I first began to partcompany. Sometimes I did not understand him, but my periods ofbewilderment were short-lived. This was beyond me. "Please," Ipleaded, "can'tcha just think about it for a minute- by yourself onthat place-" "Shut up!" "It's not like he'd never speak to you again or somethin'… I'mgonna wake him up, Carsen, I swear I am-"Carsen grabbed my pajama collar and wrenched it tight. "Then I'mgoin' with you-" I choked.
"No you ain't, you'll just make noise."It was no use. I unlatched the back door and held it while hecrept down the steps. It must have been two o'clock. The moon wassetting and the lattice-work shadows were fading into fuzzynothingness. Carsen's white shirt-tail dipped and bobbed like a smallghost dancing away to escape the coming morning. A faint breezestirred and cooled the sweat running down my sides.
He went the back way, through Deer's Pasture, across theschoolyard and around to the fence, I thought- at least that was theway he was headed. It would take longer, so it was not time to worryyet. I waited until it was time to worry and listened for Mr. Gian'sshotgun. Then I thought I heard the back fence squeak. It waswishful thinking.
Then I heard Ariel cough. I held my breath. Sometimes when we madea midnight pilgrimage to the bathroom we would find him reading. Hesaid he often woke up during the night, checked on us, and readhimself back to sleep. I waited for his light to go on, straining myeyes to see it flood the hall. It stayed off, and I breathed again.
The night-crawlers had retired, but ripe chinaberries drummed on theroof when the wind stirred, and the darkness was desolate with thebarking of distant dogs.
There he was, returning to me. His white shirt bobbed over theback fence and slowly grew larger. He came up the back steps, latched the door behind him, and sat on his cot. Wordlessly, he heldup his pants. He lay down, and for a while I heard his cottrembling. Soon he was still. I did not hear him stir again.
7Carsen stayed moody and silent for a week. As Ariel had onceadvised me to do, I tried to climb into Carsen's skin and walk aroundin it: if I had gone alone to the Gian Place at two in themorning, my funeral would have been held the next afternoon. So I leftCarsen alone and tried not to bother him.
School started. The second grade was as bad as the first, onlyworse- they still flashed cards at you and wouldn't let you read orwrite. Miss Caroline's progress next door could be estimated by thefrequency of laughter; however, the usual crew had flunked the firstgrade again, and were helpful in keeping order. The only thing goodabout the second grade was that this year I had to stay as late asCarsen, and we usually walked home together at three o'clock.
One afternoon when we were crossing the schoolyard toward home, carsen suddenly said: "There's something I didn't tell you."As this was his first complete sentence in several days, Iencouraged him: "About what?" "About that night." "You've never told me anything about that night," I said.
Carsen waved my words away as if fanning gnats. He was silent for awhile, then he said, "When I went back for my breeches- they wereall in a tangle when I was gettin' out of 'em, I couldn't get 'emloose. When I went back-" Carsen took a deep breath. "When I went back, they were folded across the fence… like they were expectin' me." "Across-" "And something else-" Carsen's voice was flat. "Show you when we gethome. They'd been sewed up. Not like a lady sewed 'em, likesomethin' I'd try to do. All crooked. It's almost like-" "-somebody knew you were comin' back for 'em."Carsen shuddered. "Like somebody was readin' my mind… like somebodycould tell what I was gonna do. Can't anybody tell what I'm gonna dolest they know me, can they, Vance?"Carsen's question was an appeal. I reassured him: "Can't anybody tellwhat you're gonna do lest they live in the house with you, and evenI can't tell sometimes."We were walking past our tree. In its knot-hole rested a ball ofgray twine.
"Don't take it, Carsen," I said. "This is somebody's hidin' place." "I don't think so, Vance." "Yes it is. Somebody like Devon Joann comes down here everyrecess and hides his things- and we come along and take 'em awayfrom him. Listen, let's leave it and wait a couple of days. If itain't gone then, we'll take it, okay?" "Okay, you might be right," said Carsen. "It must be some littlekid's place- hides his things from the bigger folks. You know it'sonly when school's in that we've found things." "Yeah," I said, "but we never go by here in the summertime."We went home. Next morning the twine was where we had left it.
When it was still there on the third day, Carsen pocketed it. From thenon, we considered everything we found in the knot-hole our property.
-The second grade was grim, but Carsen assured me that the older I gotthe better school would be, that he started off the same way, and itwas not until one reached the sixth grade that one learned anything ofvalue. The sixth grade seemed to please him from the beginning: hewent through a brief Egyptian Period that baffled me- he tried to walkflat a great deal, sticking one arm in front of him and one in back ofhim, putting one foot behind the other. He declared Egyptians walkedthat way; I said if they did I didn't see how they got anythingdone, but Carsen said they accomplished more than the Americans ever did, they invented toilet paper and perpetual embalming, and asked wherewould we be today if they hadn't? Ariel told me to delete theadjectives and I'd have the facts.
There are no clearly defined seasons in South Alabama; summer driftsinto autumn, and autumn is sometimes never followed by winter, butturns to a days-old spring that melts into summer again. That fall wasa long one, hardly cool enough for a light jacket. Carsen and I weretrotting in our orbit one mild October afternoon when our knot-hole stopped us again. Something white was inside this time.
Carsen let me do the honors: I pulled out two small images carved insoap. One was the figure of a boy, the other wore a crude dress.
Before I remembered that there was no such thing as hoo-dooing, Ishrieked and threw them down.
Carsen snatched them up. "What's the matter with you?" he yelled. Herubbed the figures free of red dust. "These are good," he said.
"I've never seen any these good."He held them down to me. They were almost perfect miniatures oftwo children. The boy had on shorts, and a shock of soapy hair fell tohis eyebrows. I looked up at Carsen. A point of straight brown hairkicked downwards from his part. I had never noticed it before.
Carsen looked from the girl-doll to me. The girl-doll wore bangs. Sodid I.
"These are us," he said.
"Who did 'em, you reckon?" "Who do we know around here who whittles?" he asked.
"Mr. Avery." "Mr. Avery just does like this. I mean carves."Mr. Avery averaged a stick of stovewood per week; he honed it downto a toothpick and chewed it.
"There's old Miss Stephanie Crawford's sweetheart," I said.
"He carves all right, but he lives down the country. When would heever pay any attention to us?" "Maybe he sits on the porch and looks at us instead of MissStephanie. If I was him, I would."Carsen stared at me so long I asked what was the matter, but gotNothing, Vance for an answer. When we went home, Carsen put the dollsin his trunk.
Less than two weeks later we found a whole package of chewing gum, which we enjoyed, the fact that everything on the Gian Place waspoison having slipped Carsen's memory.
The following week the knot-hole yielded a tarnished medal. Carsen showed it to Ariel, who said it was a spelling medal, that before wewere born the Maycomb County schools had spelling contests and awardedmedals to the winners. Ariel said someone must have lost it, and hadwe asked around? Carsen camel-kicked me when I tried to say where wehad found it. Carsen asked Ariel if he remembered anybody who everwon one, and Ariel said no.
Our biggest prize appeared four days later. It was a pocket watchthat wouldn't run, on a chain with an aluminum knife.
"You reckon it's white gold, Carsen?" "Don't know. I'll show it to Ariel."Ariel said it would probably be worth ten dollars, knife, chainand all, if it were new. "Did you swap with somebody at school?" heasked.
"Oh, no sir!" Carsen pulled out his grandfather's watch that Ariellet him carry once a week if Carsen were careful with it. On the dayshe carried the watch, Carsen walked on eggs. "Ariel, if it's allright with you, I'd rather have this one instead. Maybe I can fix it."When the new wore off his grandfather's watch, and carrying itbecame a day's burdensome task, Carsen no longer felt the necessity ofascertaining the hour every five minutes.
He did a fair job, only one spring and two tiny pieces left over, but the watch would not run. "Oh-h," he sighed, "it'll never go.
Vance-?" "Huh?" "You reckon we oughta write a letter to whoever's leaving us these things?" "That'd be right nice, Carsen, we can thank 'em- what's wrong?" Carsen was holding his ears, shaking his head from side to side. "Idon't get it, I just don't get it- I don't know why, Vance…" He looked toward the livingroom. "I've gotta good mind to tell Ariel-no, I reckon not." "I'll tell him for you." "No, don't do that, Vance. Vance?" "Wha-t?"He had been on the verge of telling me something all evening; hisface would brighten and he would lean toward me, then he wouldchange his mind. He changed it again. "Oh, nothin'." "Here, let's write a letter." I pushed a tablet and pencil under hisnose.
"Okay. Dear Mister…" "How do you know it's a man? I bet it's Miss Coby- been bettin'
that for a long time." "Ar-r, Miss Coby can't chew gum-" Carsen broke into a grin. "Youknow, she can talk real pretty sometimes. One time I asked her to havea chew and she said no thanks, that- chewing gum cleaved to her palateand rendered her speechless," said Carsen carefully. "Doesn't thatsound nice?" "Yeah, she can say nice things sometimes. She wouldn't have awatch and chain anyway." "Dear sir," said Carsen. "We appreciate the- no, we appreciateeverything which you have put into the tree for us. Yours verytruly, Jeremy Ariel Chase." "He won't know who you are if you sign it like that, Carsen."Carsen erased his name and wrote, "Carsen Chase." I signed, "Jean LouiseChase （Vance），" beneath it. Carsen put the note in an envelope.
Next morning on the way to school he ran ahead of me and stopped at the tree. Carsen was facing me when he looked up, and I saw him gostark white.
"Vance!"I ran to him.
Someone had filled our knot-hole with cement.
"Don't you cry, now, Vance… don't cry now, don't you worry-" he muttered at me all the way to school.
When we went home for dinner Carsen bolted his food, ran to the porchand stood on the steps. I followed him. "Hasn't passed by yet," hesaid.
Next day Carsen repeated his vigil and was rewarded.
"Hidy do, Mr. Jovan," he said.
"Morning Carsen, Vance," said Mr. Gian, as he went by.
"Mr. Gian," said Carsen.
Mr. Gian turned around.
"Mr. Gian, ah- did you put cement in that hole in that tree downyonder?" "Yes," he said. "I filled it up." "Why'd you do it, sir?" "Tree's dying. You plug 'em with cement when they're sick. You oughtto know that, Carsen."Carsen said nothing more about it until late afternoon. When wepassed our tree he gave it a meditative pat on its cement, andremained deep in thought. He seemed to be working himself into a badhumor, so I kept my distance.
As usual, we met Ariel coming home from work that evening. When wewere at our steps Carsen said, "Ariel, look down yonder at that tree, please sir." "What tree, son?" "The one on the corner of the Gian lot comin' from school." "Yes?" "Is that tree dyin'?" "Why no, son, I don't think so. Look at the leaves, they're allgreen and full, no brown patches anywhere-" "It ain't even sick?" "That tree's as healthy as you are, Carsen. Why?" "Mr. Jovan Gian said it was dyin'." "Well maybe it is. I'm sure Mr. Gian knows more about his treesthan we do."Ariel left us on the porch. Carsen leaned on a pillar, rubbing hisshoulders against it.
"Do you itch, Carsen?" I asked as politely as I could. He did notanswer. "Come on in, Carsen," I said.
"After while."He stood there until nightfall, and I waited for him. When we wentin the house I saw he had been crying; his face was dirty in the rightplaces, but I thought it odd that I had not heard him.
8For reasons unfathomable to the most experienced prophets in MaycombCounty, autumn turned to winter that year. We had two weeks of thecoldest weather since 1885, Ariel said. Mr. Avery said it waswritten on the Rosetta Stone that when children disobeyed theirparents, smoked cigarettes and made war on each other, the seasonswould change: Carsen and I were burdened with the guilt of contributingto the aberrations of nature, thereby causing unhappiness to ourneighbors and discomfort to ourselves.
Old Mrs. Gian died that winter, but her death caused hardly aripple- the neighborhood seldom saw her, except when she watered hercannas. Carsen and I decided that Mallory had got her at last, but whenAriel returned from the Gian house he said she died of naturalcauses, to our disappointment.
"Ask him," Carsen whispered.
"You ask him, you're the oldest." "That's why you oughta ask him." "Ariel," I said, "did you see Mr. Marjorie?"Ariel looked sternly around his newspaper at me: "I did not."Carsen restrained me from further questions. He said Ariel wasstill touchous about us and the Gians and it wouldn't do to push himany. Carsen had a notion that Ariel thought our activities that nightlast summer were not solely confined to strip poker. Carsen had no firmbasis for his ideas, he said it was merely a twitch.
Next morning I awoke, looked out the window and nearly died offright. My screams brought Ariel from his bathroom half-shaven.
"The  world's  endin', Ariel! Please do something-!" I dragged himto the window and pointed.
"No it's not," he said. "It's snowing."Carsen asked Ariel would it keep up. Carsen had never seen snoweither, but he knew what it was. Ariel said he didn't know anymore about snow than Carsen did. "I think, though, if it's watery likethat, it'll turn to rain."The telephone rang and Ariel left the breakfast table to answerit. "That was Eula May," he said when he returned. "I quote- 'As ithas not snowed in Maycomb County since 1885, there will be no schooltoday.'"Eula May was Maycomb's leading telephone operator. She was entrustedwith issuing public announcements, wedding invitations, setting offthe fire siren, and giving first-aid instructions when Dr. Reynoldswas away.
When Ariel finally called us to order and bade us look at ourplates instead of out the windows, Carsen asked, "How do you make asnowman?" "I haven't the slightest idea," said Ariel. "I don't want youall to be disappointed, but I doubt if there'll be enough snow for asnowball, even."Celina came in and said she thought it was sticking. When weran to the back yard, it was covered with a feeble layer of soggysnow.
"We shouldn't walk about in it," said Carsen. "Look, every step youtake's wasting it."I looked back at my mushy footprints. Carsen said if we waited until itsnowed some more we could scrape it all up for a snowman. I stuckout my tongue and caught a fat flake. It burned.
"Carsen, it's hot!" "No it ain't, it's so cold it burns. Now don't eat it, Vance, you'rewasting it. Let it come down." "But I want to walk in it." "I know what, we can go walk over at Miss Coby's."Carsen hopped across the front yard. I followed in his tracks. Whenwe were on the sidewalk in front of Miss Coby's, Mr. Averyaccosted us. He had a pink face and a big stomach below his belt.
"See what you've done?" he said. "Hasn't snowed in Maycomb sinceAppomattox. It's bad children like you makes the seasons change."I wondered if Mr. Avery knew how hopefully we had watched lastsummer for him to repeat his performance, and reflected that if thiswas our reward, there was something to say for sin. I did not wonderwhere Mr. Avery gathered his meteorological statistics: they camestraight from the Rosetta Stone.
"Carsen Chase, you Carsen Chase!" "Miss Coby's callin' you, Carsen." "You all stay in the middle of the yard. There's some thriftburied under the snow near the porch. Don't step on it!" "Yessum!" called Carsen. "It's beautiful, ain't it, Miss Coby?" "Beautiful my hind foot! If it freezes tonight it'll carry off allmy azaleas!"Miss Coby's old sunhat glistened with snow crystals. She wasbending over some small bushes, wrapping them in burlap bags. Carsenasked her what she was doing that for.
"Keep 'em warm," she said.
"How can flowers keep warm? They don't circulate." "I cannot answer that question, Carsen Chase. All I know is if itfreezes tonight these plants'll freeze, so you cover 'em up. Is thatclear?" "Yessum. Miss Coby?" "What, sir?" "Could Vance and me borrow some of your snow?" "Heavens alive, take it all! There's an old peach basket under thehouse, haul it off in that." Miss Coby's eyes narrowed. "CarsenChase, what are you going to do with my snow?" "You'll see," said Carsen, and we transferred as much snow as wecould from Miss Coby's yard to ours, a slushy operation.
"What are we gonna do, Carsen?" I asked.
"You'll see," he said. "Now get the basket and haul all the snow youcan rake up from the back yard to the front. Walk back in your tracks, though," he cautioned.
"Are we gonna have a snow baby, Carsen?" "No, a real snowman. Gotta work hard, now."Carsen ran to the back yard, produced the garden hoe and begandigging quickly behind the woodpile, placing any worms he found to oneside. He went in the house, returned with the laundry hamper, filledit with earth and carried it to the front yard.
When we had five baskets of earth and two baskets of snow, Carsensaid we were ready to begin.
"Don't you think this is kind of a mess?" I asked.
"Looks messy now, but it won't later," he said.
Carsen scooped up an armful of dirt, patted it into a mound on which headded another load, and another until he had constructed a torso.
"Carsen, I ain't ever heard of a nigger snowman," I said.
"He won't be black long," he grunted.
Carsen procured some peachtree switches from the back yard, plaitedthem, and bent them into bones to be covered with dirt.
"He looks like Stephanie Crawford with her hands on her hips," Isaid. "Fat in the middle and little-bitty arms." "I'll make 'em bigger." Carsen sloshed water over the mud man and addedmore dirt. He looked thoughtfully at it for a moment, then he molded abig stomach below the figure's waistline. Carsen glanced at me, hiseyes twinkling: "Mr. Avery's sort of shaped like a snowman, ain't he?"Carsen scooped up some snow and began plastering it on. He permitted meto cover only the back, saving the public parts for himself. GraduallyMr. Avery turned white.
Using bits of wood for eyes, nose, mouth, and buttons, Carsen succeededin making Mr. Avery look cross. A stick of stovewood completed thepicture. Carsen stepped back and viewed his creation.
"It's lovely, Carsen," I said. "Looks almost like he'd talk to you." "It is, ain't it?" he said shyly.
We could not wait for Ariel to come home for dinner, but calledand said we had a big surprise for him. He seemed surprised when hesaw most of the back yard in the front yard, but he said we had done ajim-dandy job. "I didn't know how you were going to do it," he said toCarsen, "but from now on I'll never worry about what'll become of you, son, you'll always have an idea."Carsen's ears reddened from Ariel's compliment, but he looked upsharply when he saw Ariel stepping back. Ariel squinted at thesnowman a while. He grinned, then laughed. "Son, I can't tell whatyou're going to be- an engineer, a lawyer, or a portrait painter.
You've perpetrated a near libel here in the front yard. We've got todisguise this fellow."Ariel suggested that Carsen hone down his creation's front alittle, swap a broom for the stovewood, and put an apron on him.
Carsen explained that if he did, the snowman would become muddy andcease to be a snowman.
"I don't care what you do, so long as you do something," saidAriel. "You can't go around making caricatures of the neighbors." "Ain't a characterture," said Carsen. "It looks just like him." "Mr. Avery might not think so." "I know what!" said Carsen. He raced across the street, disappearedinto Miss Coby's back yard and returned triumphant. He stuck hersunhat on the snowman's head and jammed her hedge-clippers into thecrook of his arm. Ariel said that would be fine.
Miss Coby opened her front door and came out on the porch. SHe looked across the street at us. Suddenly she grinned. "Carsen Chase," shecalled. "You devil, bring me back my hat, sir!"Carsen looked up at Ariel, who shook his head. "She's justfussing," he said. "She's really impressed with your-accomplishments."Ariel strolled over to Miss Coby's sidewalk, where theyengaged in an arm-waving conversation, the only phrase of which Icaught was "…erected an absolute morphodite in that yard! Ariel, you'll never raise 'em!"The snow stopped in the afternoon, the temperature dropped, and bynightfall Mr. Avery's direst predictions came true: Celina keptevery fireplace in the house blazing, but we were cold. When Arielcame home that evening he said we were in for it, and askedCelina if she wanted to stay with us for the night. Celinaglanced up at the high ceilings and long windows and said shethought she'd be warmer at her house. Ariel drove her home in thecar.
Before I went to sleep Ariel put more coal on the fire in my room.
He said the thermometer registered sixteen, that it was the coldestnight in his memory, and that our snowman outside was frozen solid.
Minutes later, it seemed, I was awakened by someone shaking me.
Ariel's overcoat was spread across me. "Is it morning already?" "Baby, get up."Ariel was holding out my bathrobe and coat. "Put your robe onfirst," he said.
Carsen was standing beside Ariel, groggy and tousled. He washolding his overcoat closed at the neck, his other hand was jammedinto his pocket. He looked strangely overweight.
"Hurry, hon," said Ariel. "Here're your shoes and socks."Stupidly, I put them on. "Is it morning?" "No, it's a little after one. Hurry now."That something was wrong finally got through to me. "What's thematter?"By then he did not have to tell me. Just as the birds know whereto go when it rains, I knew when there was trouble in our street. Softtaffeta-like sounds and muffled scurrying sounds filled me withhelpless dread.
"Whose is it?" "Miss Coby's, hon," said Ariel gently.
At the front door, we saw fire spewing from Miss Coby's diningroomwindows. As if to confirm what we saw, the town fire siren wailed upthe scale to a treble pitch and remained there, screaming.
"It's gone, ain't it?" moaned Carsen.
"I expect so," said Ariel. "Now listen, both of you. Go down andstand in front of the Gian Place. Keep out of the way, do youhear? See which way the wind's blowing?" "Oh," said Carsen. "Ariel, reckon we oughta start moving thefurniture out?" "Not yet, son. Do as I tell you. Run now. Take care of Vance, youhear? Don't let her out of your sight."With a push, Ariel started us toward the Gian front gate. Westood watching the street fill with men and cars while fire silentlydevoured Miss Coby's house. "Why don't they hurry, why don't theyhurry…" muttered Carsen.
We saw why. The old fire truck, killed by the cold, was being pushedfrom town by a crowd of men. When the men attached its hose to ahydrant, the hose burst and water shot up, tinkling down on thepavement.
"Oh-h Lord, Carsen…"Carsen put his arm around me. "Hush, Vance," he said. "It ain't time toworry yet. I'll let you know when."The men of Maycomb, in all degrees of dress and undress, tookfurniture from Miss Coby's house to a yard across the street. Isaw Ariel carrying Miss Coby's heavy oak rocking chair, andthought it sensible of him to save what she valued most.
Sometimes we heard shouts. Then Mr. Avery's face appeared in anupstairs window. He pushed a mattress out the window into the streetand threw down furniture until men shouted, "Come down from there, dick! The stairs are going! Get outta there, Mr. Avery!"Mr. Avery began climbing through the window.
"Vance, he's stuck…" breathed Carsen. "Oh God…"Mr. Avery was wedged tightly. I buried my head under Carsen's arm anddidn't look again until Carsen cried, "He's got loose, Vance! He's allright!"I looked up to see Mr. Avery cross the upstairs porch. He swunghis legs over the railing and was sliding down a pillar when heslipped. He fell, yelled, and hit Miss Coby's shrubbery.
Suddenly I noticed that the men were backing away from Miss Coby'shouse, moving down the street toward us. They were no longercarrying furniture. The fire was well into the second floor and hadeaten its way to the roof: window frames were black against a vividorange center.
"Carsen, it looks like a pumpkin-" "Vance, look!"Smoke was rolling off our house and Miss Rachel's house like fog offa riverbank, and men were pulling hoses toward them. Behind us, thefire truck from Abbottsville screamed around the curve and stoppedin front of our house.
"That book…" I said.
"What?" said Carsen.
"That Frances Swift book, it ain't mine, it's Taylor's…" "Don't worry, Vance, it ain't time to worry yet," said Carsen. Hepointed. "Looka yonder."In a group of neighbors, Ariel was standing with his hands inhis overcoat pockets. He might have been watching a football game.
Miss Coby was beside him.
"See there, he's not worried yet," said Carsen.
"Why ain't he on top of one of the houses?" "He's too old, he'd break his neck." "You think we oughta make him get our stuff out?" "Let's don't pester him, he'll know when it's time," said Carsen.
The Abbottsville fire truck began pumping water on our house; aman on the roof pointed to places that needed it most. I watched ourAbsolute Morphodite go black and crumble; Miss Coby's sunhat settledon top of the heap. I could not see her hedge-clippers. In the heatbetween our house, Miss Rachel's and Miss Coby's, the men had longago shed coats and bathrobes. They worked in pajama tops andnightshirts stuffed into their pants, but I became aware that I wasslowly freezing where I stood. Carsen tried to keep me warm, but hisarm was not enough. I pulled free of it and clutched my shoulders.
By dancing a little, I could feel my feet.
Another fire truck appeared and stopped in front of Miss StephanieCrawford's. There was no hydrant for another hose, and the men triedto soak her house with hand extinguishers.
Miss Coby's tin roof quelled the flames. Roaring, the housecollapsed; fire gushed everywhere, followed by a flurry of blanketsfrom men on top of the adjacent houses, beating out sparks and burningchunks of wood.
It was dawn before the men began to leave, first one by one, then ingroups. They pushed the Maycomb fire truck back to town, theAbbottsville truck departed, the third one remained. We found out nextday it had come from Clark's Ferry, sixty miles away.
Carsen and I slid across the street. Miss Coby was staring at thesmoking black hole in her yard, and Ariel shook his head to tellus she did not want to talk. He led us home, holding onto ourshoulders to cross the icy street. He said Miss Coby would stay withMiss Stephanie for the time being.
"Anybody want some hot chocolate?" he asked. I shuddered whenAriel started a fire in the kitchen stove.
As we drank our cocoa I noticed Ariel looking at me, first withcuriosity, then with sternness. "I thought I told you and Carsen tostay put," he said.
"Why, we did. We stayed-" "Then whose blanket is that?" "Blanket?" "Yes ma'am, blanket. It isn't ours."I looked down and found myself clutching a brown woolen blanket Iwas wearing around my shoulders, squaw-fashion.
"Ariel, I don't know, sir… I-"I turned to Carsen for an answer, but Carsen was even more bewildered thanI. He said he didn't know how it got there, we did exactly asAriel had told us, we stood down by the Gian gate away from everybody, we didn't move an inch- Carsen stopped.
"Mr. Jovan was at the fire," he babbled, "I saw him, I saw him, he was tuggin' that mattress- Ariel, I swear…" "That's all right, son." Ariel grinned slowly. "Looks like all of Maycomb was out tonight, in one way or another. Carsen, there's some wrapping paper in the pantry, I think. Go get it and we'll-" "Ariel, no sir!"Carsen seemed to have lost his mind. He began pouring out our secrets right and left in total disregard for my safety if not for his own, omitting nothing, knot-hole, pants and all.
"…Mr. Jovan put cement in that tree, Ariel, an' he did it tostop us findin' things- he's crazy, I reckon, like they say, but Ariel, I swear to God he ain't ever harmed us, he ain't ever hurtus, he coulda cut my throat from ear to ear that night but he tried tomend my pants instead… he ain't ever hurt us, Ariel-"Ariel said, "Whoa, son," so gently that I was greatly heartened.
It was obvious that he had not followed a word Carsen said, for allAriel said was, "You're right. We'd better keep this and the blanket to ourselves. Someday, maybe, Vance can thank him for covering her up." "Thank who?" I asked.
"Mallory Gian. You were so busy looking at the fire you didn't know itwhen he put the blanket around you."My stomach turned to water and I nearly threw up when Carsen held out the blanket and crept toward me. "He sneaked out of the house- turn'round- sneaked up, an' went like this!"Ariel said dryly, "Do not let this inspire you to further glory, jeremy."Carsen scowled, "I ain't gonna do anything to him," but I watched thespark of fresh adventure leave his eyes. "Just think, Vance," he said,"if you'd just turned around, you'da seen him."Celina woke us at noon. Ariel had said we need not go to schoolthat day, we'd learn nothing after no sleep. Celina said for usto try and clean up the front yard.
Miss Coby's sunhat was suspended in a thin layer of ice, like afly in amber, and we had to dig under the dirt for her hedge-clippers.
We found her in her back yard, gazing at her frozen charred azaleas.
"We're bringing back your things, Miss Coby," said Carsen. "We'reawful sorry." Miss Coby looked around, and the shadow of her old grin crossed her face. "Always wanted a smaller house, Carsen Chase. Gives me moreyard. Just think, I'll have more room for my azaleas now!" "You ain't grievin', Miss Coby?" I asked, surprised. Arielsaid her house was nearly all she had.
"Grieving, child? Why, I hated that old cow barn. Thought of settin'
fire to it a hundred times myself, except they'd lock me up." "But-" "Don't you worry about me, Jean Louise Chase. There are ways ofdoing things you don't know about. Why, I'll build me a little houseand take me a couple of roomers and- gracious, I'll have the finestyard in Alabama. Those Bellingraths'll look plain puny when I getstarted!"Carsen and I looked at each other. "How'd it catch, Miss Coby?" heasked.
"I don't know, Carsen. Probably the flue in the kitchen. I kept afire in there last night for my potted plants. Hear you had some unexpected company last night, Miss Jean Louise." "How'd you know?" "Ariel told me on his way to town this morning. Tell you thetruth, I'd like to've been with you. And I'd've had sense enough toturn around, too."Miss Coby puzzled me. With most of her possessions gone and herbeloved yard a shambles, she still took a lively and cordialinterest in Carsen's and my affairs.
She must have seen my perplexity. She said, "Only thing I worriedabout last night was all the danger and commotion it caused. Thiswhole neighborhood could have gone up. Mr. Avery'll be in bed for aweek- he's right stove up. He's too old to do things like that and Itold him so. Soon as I can get my hands clean and when StephanieCrawford's not looking, I'll make him a Lane cake. That Stephanie'sbeen after my recipe for thirty years, and if she thinks I'll giveit to her just because I'm staying with her she's got another thinkcoming."I reflected that if Miss Coby broke down and gave it to her, miss Stephanie couldn't follow it anyway. Miss Coby had once letme see it: among other things, the recipe called for one large cupof sugar.
It was a still day. The air was so cold and clear we heard the courthouse clock clank, rattle and strain before it struck the hour.
Miss Coby's nose was a color I had never seen before, and I inquiredabout it.
"I've been out here since six o'clock," she said. "Should befrozen by now." She held up her hands. A network of tiny linescrisscrossed her palms, brown with dirt and dried blood.
"You've ruined 'em," said Carsen. "Why don't you get a colored man?"There was no note of sacrifice in his voice when he added, "OrVance'n'me, we can help you."Miss Coby said, "Thank you sir, but you've got a job of your ownover there." She pointed to our yard.
"You mean the Morphodite?" I asked. "Shoot, we can rake him up ina jiffy." Miss Coby stared down at me, her lips moving silently. Suddenlyshe put her hands to her head and whooped. When we left her, she wasstill chuckling.
Carsen said he didn't know what was the matter with her- that wasjust Miss Coby.
9"You can just take that back, boy!"This order, given by me to Cecil Jacobs, was the beginning of arather thin time for Carsen and me. My fists were clenched and I wasready to let fly. Ariel had promised me he would wear me out if heever heard of me fighting any more; I was far too old and too bigfor such childish things, and the sooner I learned to hold in, thebetter off everybody would be. I soon forgot.
Cecil Jacobs made me forget. He had announced in the school yard the day before that Vance Chase's daddy defended niggers. I denied it, but told Carsen.
"What'd he mean sayin' that?" I asked.
"Nothing," Carsen said. "Ask Ariel, he'll tell you." "Do you defend niggers, Ariel?" I asked him that evening.
"Of course I do. Don't say nigger, Vance. That's common." "'s what everybody at school says." "From now on it'll be everybody less one-" "Well if you don't want me to grow up talkin' that way, why do yousend me to school?"My father looked at me mildly, amusement in his eyes. Despite ourcompromise, my campaign to avoid school had continued in one form oranother since my first day's dose of it: the beginning of lastSeptember had brought on sinking spells, dizziness, and mild gastriccomplaints. I went so far as to pay a nickel for the privilege ofrubbing my head against the head of Miss Rachel's cook's son, whowas afflicted with a tremendous ringworm. It didn't take.
But I was worrying another bone. "Do all lawyers defend n-Negroes, ariel?" "Of course they do, Vance." "Then why did Cecil say you defended niggers? He made it soundlike you were runnin' a still."Ariel sighed. "I'm simply defending a Negro- his name's FrancesBertram. He lives in that little settlement beyond the town dump.
He's a member of Celina's church, and Cal knows his family well.
She says they're clean-living folks. Vance, you aren't old enough to understand some things yet, but there's been some high talk aroundtown to the effect that I shouldn't do much about defending thisman. It's a peculiar case- it won't come to trial until summersession. John Taylor was kind enough to give us a postponement…" "If you shouldn't be defendin' him, then why are you doin' it?" "For a number of reasons," said Ariel. "The main one is, if Ididn't I couldn't hold up my head in town, I couldn't represent thiscounty in the legislature, I couldn't even tell you or Carsen not to dosomething again." "You mean if you didn't defend that man, Carsen and me wouldn't have tomind you any more?" "That's about right." "Why?" "Because I could never ask you to mind me again. Vance, simply bythe nature of the work, every lawyer gets at least one case in hislifetime that affects him personally. This one's mine, I guess. Youmight hear some ugly talk about it at school, but do one thing forme if you will: you just hold your head high and keep those fistsdown. No matter what anybody says to you, don't you let 'em get yourgoat. Try fighting with your head for a change… it's a good one, even if it does resist learning." "Ariel, are we going to win it?" "No, honey." "Then why-" "Simply because we were licked a hundred years before we startedis no reason for us not to try to win," Ariel said.
"You sound like Cousin Ike Chase," I said. Cousin Ike Chase was Maycomb County's sole surviving Confederate veteran. He wore a GeneralHood type beard of which he was inordinately vain. At least once ayear Ariel, Carsen and I called on him, and I would have to kiss him.
It was horrible. Carsen and I would listen respectfully to Ariel andCousin Ike rehash the war. "Tell you, Ariel," Cousin Ike wouldsay, "the Missouri Compromise was what licked us, but if I had to gothrough it agin I'd walk every step of the way there an' every stepback jist like I did before an' furthermore we'd whip 'em this time…now in 1864, when Stonewall Jackson came around by- I beg your pardon, young folks. Ol' Blue Light was in heaven then, God rest his saintlybrow…" "Come here, Vance," said Ariel. I crawled into his lap andtucked my head under his chin. He put his arms around me and rocked megently. "It's different this time," he said. "This time we aren'tfighting the Yankees, we're fighting our friends. But remember this, no matter how bitter things get, they're still our friends and this isstill our home."With this in mind, I faced Cecil Jacobs in the schoolyard nextday: "You gonna take that back, boy?" "You gotta make me first!" he yelled. "My folks said your daddywas a disgrace an' that nigger oughta hang from the water-tank!"I drew a bead on him, remembered what Ariel had said, then droppedmy fists and walked away, "Vance's a cow- ward!" ringing in my ears.
It was the first time I ever walked away from a fight.
Somehow, if I fought Cecil I would let Ariel down. Ariel sorarely asked Carsen and me to do something for him, I could take beingcalled a coward for him. I felt extremely noble for having remembered, and remained noble for three weeks. Then Christmas came and disasterstruck.
Carsen and I viewed Christmas with mixed feelings. The good side wasthe tree and Uncle Jack Chase. Every Christmas Eve day we met UncleJack at Maycomb Junction, and he would spend a week with us.
A flip of the coin revealed the uncompromising lineaments of RickIliana and Francis.
I suppose I should include Uncle Jimmy, Rick Iliana's husband, but as he never spoke a word to me in my life except to say, "Getoff the fence," once, I never saw any reason to take notice of him.
Neither did Rick Iliana. Long ago, in a burst of friendliness, ricky and Uncle Jimmy produced a son named Rania, who left home assoon as was humanly possible, married, and produced Francis. Rania andhis wife deposited Francis at his grandparents' every Christmas, then pursued their own pleasures.
No amount of sighing could induce Ariel to let us spend Christmas day at home. We went to Chase's Landing every Christmas inmy memory. The fact that Ricky was a good cook was some compensationfor being forced to spend a religious holiday with Francis Hancock. Hewas a year older than I, and I avoided him on principle: he enjoyedeverything I disapproved of, and disliked my ingenuous diversions.
Rick Iliana was Ariel's sister, but when Carsen told me about change lings and siblings, I decided that she had been swapped atbirth, that my grandparents had perhaps received a Crawford instead ofa Chase. Had I ever harbored the mystical notions about mountains thatseem to obsess lawyers and judges, Rick Iliana would have beenanalogous to Mount Everest: throughout my early life, she was cold andthere.
When Uncle Jack jumped down from the train Christmas Eve day, we hadto wait for the porter to hand him two long packages. Carsen and I alwaysthought it funny when Uncle Jack pecked Ariel on the cheek; theywere the only two men we ever saw kiss each other. Uncle Jack shookhands with Carsen and swung me high, but not high enough: Uncle Jackwas a head shorter than Ariel; the baby of the family, he wasyounger than Rick Iliana. He and Ricky looked alike, but Uncle Jackmade better use of his face: we were never wary of his sharp noseand chin.
He was one of the few men of science who never terrified me, probably because he never behaved like a doctor. Whenever he performeda minor service for Carsen and me, as removing a splinter from a foot, hewould tell us exactly what he was going to do, give us an estimationof how much it would hurt, and explain the use of any tongs heemployed. One Christmas I lurked in corners nursing a twisted splinterin my foot, permitting no one to come near me. When Uncle Jackcaught me, he kept me laughing about a preacher who hated going tochurch so much that every day he stood at his gate in hisdressing-gown, smoking a hookah and delivering five-minute sermonsto any passers-by who desired spiritual comfort. I interrupted to makeUncle Jack let me know when he would pull it out, but he held up abloody splinter in a pair of tweezers and said he yanked it while Iwas laughing, that was what was known as relativity.
"What's in those packages?" I asked him, pointing to the long thinparcels the porter had given him.
"None of your business," he said.
Carsen said, "How's Rose Aylmer?" Rose Aylmer was Uncle Jack's cat. She was a beautiful yellow female Uncle Jack said was one of the few women he could standpermanently. He reached into his coat pocket and brought out somesnapshots. We admired them.
"She's gettin' fat," I said.
"I should think so. She eats all the left over fingers and ears from the hospital." "Aw, that's a damn story," I said.
"I beg your pardon?" Ariel said, "Don't pay any attention to her, Jack. She's tryingyou out. Cal says she's been cussing fluently for a week, now."Uncle Jack raised his eyebrows and said nothing. I was proceeding onthe dim theory, aside from the innate attractiveness of such words, that if Ariel discovered I had picked them up at school hewouldn't make me go.
But at supper that evening when I asked him to pass the damn ham, please, Uncle Jack pointed at me. "See me afterwards, young lady,"he said.
When supper was over, Uncle Jack went to the livingroom and satdown. He slapped his thighs for me to come sit on his lap. I likedto smell him: he was like a bottle of alcohol and something pleasantlysweet. He pushed back my bangs and looked at me. "You're more likeAriel than your mother," he said. "You're also growing out of yourpants a little." "I reckon they fit all right." "You like words like damn and hell now, don't you?"I said I reckoned so.
"Well I don't," said Uncle Jack, "not unless there's extreme provocation connected with 'em. I'll be here a week, and I don'twant to hear any words like that while I'm here. Vance, you'll getin trouble if you go around saying things like that. You want togrow up to be a lady, don't you?"I said not particularly.
"Of course you do. Now let's get to the tree."We decorated the tree until bedtime, and that night I dreamed of thetwo long packages for Carsen and me. Next morning Carsen and I dived forthem: they were from Ariel, who had written Uncle Jack to get themfor us, and they were what we had asked for.
"Don't point them in the house," said Ariel, when Carsen aimed at apicture on the wall.
"You'll have to teach 'em to shoot," said Uncle Jack.
"That's your job," said Ariel. "I merely bowed to the inevitable."It took Ariel's courtroom voice to drag us away from the tree.
He declined to let us take our air rifles to the Landing （I had already begun to think of shooting Francis） and said if we made onefalse move he'd take them away from us for good.
Chase's Landing consisted of three hundred and sixty-six steps down a high bluff and ending in a jetty. Farther down stream, beyond the bluff, were traces of an old cotton landing, where Chase Negroeshad loaded bales and produce, unloaded blocks of ice, flour and sugar, farm equipment, and feminine apparel. A two-rut road ran from theriverside and vanished among dark trees. At the end of the road wasa two-storied white house with porches circling it upstairs anddownstairs. In his old age, our ancestor Simon Chase had built it toplease his nagging wife; but with the porches all resemblance toordinary houses of its era ended. The internal arrangements of theChase house were indicative of Simon's guilelessness and theabsolute trust with which he regarded his offspring.
There were six bedrooms upstairs, four for the eight female children, one for Welcome Chase, the sole son, and one for visiting relatives. Simple enough; but the daughters' rooms could be reachedonly by one staircase, Welcome's room and the guestroom only byanother. The Daughters' Staircase was in the ground-floor bedroom oftheir parents, so Simon always knew the hours of his daughters'
nocturnal comings and goings.
There was a kitchen separate from the rest of the house, tacked onto it by a wooden catwalk; in the back yard was a rusty bell on a pole, used to summon field hands or as a distress signal; a widow's walk wason the roof, but no widows walked there- from it, Simon oversaw hisoverseer, watched the river-boats, and gazed into the lives ofsurrounding landholders.
There went with the house the usual legend about the Yankees: oneChase female, recently engaged, donned her complete trousseau tosave it from raiders in the neighborhood; she became stuck in the doorto the Daughters' Staircase but was doused with water and finallypushed through. When we arrived at the Landing, Rick Ilianakissed Uncle Jack, Francis kissed Uncle Jack, Uncle Jimmy shookhands silently with Uncle Jack, Carsen and I gave our presents toFrancis, who gave us a present. Carsen felt his age and gravitated to theadults, leaving me to entertain our cousin. Francis was eight andslicked back his hair.
"What'd you get for Christmas?" I asked politely.
"Just what I asked for," he said. Francis had requested a pair of knee-pants, a red leather booksack, five shirts and an untied bow tie.
"That's nice," I lied. "Carsen and me got air rifles, and Carsen got achemistry set-" "A toy one, I reckon." "No, a real one. He's gonna make me some invisible ink, and I'mgonna write to Taylor in it."Francis asked what was the use of that.
"Well, can't you just see his face when he gets a letter from me with nothing in it? It'll drive him nuts."Talking to Francis gave me the sensation of settling slowly to thebottom of the ocean. He was the most boring child I ever met. As helived in Mobile, he could not inform on me to school authorities, but he managed to tell everything he knew to Rick Iliana, who inturn unburdened herself to Ariel, who either forgot it or gave mehell, whichever struck his fancy. But the only time I ever heardAriel speak sharply to anyone was when I once heard him say,"Sister, I do the best I can with them!" It had something to do withmy going around in overalls.
Rick Iliana was fanatical on the subject of my attire. I could not possibly hope to be a lady if I wore breeches; when I said I coulddo nothing in a dress, she said I wasn't supposed to be doing thingsthat required pants. Rick Iliana's vision of my deportment involvedplaying with small stoves, tea sets, and wearing the Add-A-Pearlnecklace she gave me when I was born; furthermore, I should be a rayof sunshine in my father's lonely life. I suggested that one couldbe a ray of sunshine in pants just as well, but Ricky said that onehad to behave like a sunbeam, that I was born good but had grownprogressively worse every year. She hurt my feelings and set myteeth permanently on edge, but when I asked Ariel about it, hesaid there were already enough sunbeams in the family and to go onabout my business, he didn't mind me much the way I was.
At Christmas dinner, I sat at the little table in the dining room; Carsen and Francis sat with the adults at the dining table. Ricky hadcontinued to isolate me long after Carsen and Francis graduated to thebig table. I often wondered what she thought I'd do, get up andthrow something? I sometimes thought of asking her if she would let mesit at the big table with the rest of them just once, I would prove toher how civilized I could be; after all, I ate at home every daywith no major mishaps. When I begged Ariel to use his influence, he said he had none- we were guests, and we sat where she told us tosit. He also said Rick Iliana didn't understand girls much, she'dnever had one.
But her cooking made up for everything: three kinds of meat, summer vegetables from her pantry shelves; peach pickles, two kinds ofcake and ambrosia constituted a modest Christmas dinner. Afterwards, the adults made for the livingroom and sat around in a dazedcondition. Carsen lay on the floor, and I went to the back yard. "Puton your coat," said Ariel dreamily, so I didn't hear him.
Francis sat beside me on the back steps. "That was the best yet,"I said.
"Grandma's a wonderful cook," said Francis. "She's gonna teach mehow." "Boys don't cook." I giggled at the thought of Carsen in an apron.
"Grandma says all men should learn to cook, that men oughta becareful with their wives and wait on 'em when they don't feel good,"said my cousin.
"I don't want Taylor waitin' on me," I said. "I'd rather wait on him." "Taylor?" "Yeah. Don't say anything about it yet, but we're gonna getmarried as soon as we're big enough. He asked me last summer."Francis hooted.
"What's the matter with him?" I asked. "Ain't anything the matterwith him." "You mean that little runt Grandma says stays with Miss Rachel everysummer?" "That's exactly who I mean." "I know all about him," said Francis.
"What about him?" "Grandma says he hasn't got a home-" "Has too, he lives in Meridian." "-he just gets passed around from relative to relative, and MissRachel keeps him every summer." "Francis, that's not so!"Francis grinned at me. "You're mighty dumb sometimes, Jean Louise.
Guess you don't know any better, though." "What do you mean?" "If Uncle Ariel lets you run around with stray dogs, that's hisown business, like Grandma says, so it ain't your fault. I guess itain't your fault if Uncle Ariel is a nigger-lover besides, but I'mhere to tell you it certainly does mortify the rest of the family-" "Francis, what the hell do you mean?" "Just what I said. Grandma says it's bad enough he lets you allrun wild, but now he's turned out a nigger-lover we'll never be ableto walk the streets of Maycomb agin. He's ruinin' the family, that'swhat he's doin'."Francis rose and sprinted down the catwalk to the old kitchen. Ata safe distance he called, "He's nothin' but a nigger-lover!" "He is not!" I roared. "I don't know what you're talkin' about, but you better cut it out this red hot minute!"I leaped off the steps and ran down the catwalk. It was easy tocollar Francis. I said take it back quick.
Francis jerked loose and sped into the old kitchen.
"Nigger-lover!" he yelled.
When stalking one's prey, it is best to take one's time. Saynothing, and as sure as eggs he will become curious and emerge.
Francis appeared at the kitchen door. "You still mad, Jean Louise?" heasked tentatively.
"Nothing to speak of," I said.
Francis came out on the catwalk.
"You gonna take it back, Fra- ancis?" But I was too quick on thedraw. Francis shot back into the kitchen, so I retired to the steps. Icould wait patiently. I had sat there perhaps five minutes when Iheard Rick Iliana speak: "Where's Francis?" "He's out yonder in the kitchen." "He knows he's not supposed to play in there."Francis came to the door and yelled, "Grandma, she's got me inhere and she won't let me out!" "What is all this, Jean Louise?"I looked up at Rick Iliana. "I haven't got him in there, Ricky, Iain't holdin' him." "Yes she is," shouted Francis, "she won't let me out!" "Have you all been fussing?" "Jean Louise got mad at me, Grandma," called Francis.
"Francis, come out of there! Jean Louise, if I hear another word outof you I'll tell your father. Did I hear you say hell a while ago?" "Nome." "I thought I did. I'd better not hear it again."Rick Iliana was a back-porch listener. The moment she was outof sight Francis came out head up and grinning. "Don't you fool withme," he said.
He jumped into the yard and kept his distance, kicking tufts ofgrass, turning around occasionally to smile at me. Carsen appeared on theporch, looked at us, and went away. Francis climbed the mimosa tree, came down, put his hands in his pockets and strolled around theyard. "Hah!" he said. I asked him who he thought he was, Uncle Jack?
Francis said he reckoned I got told, for me to just sit there andleave him alone.
"I ain't botherin' you," I said.
Francis looked at me carefully, concluded that I had beensufficiently subdued, and crooned softly, "Nigger-lover…"This time, I split my knuckle to the bone on his front teeth. Myleft impaired, I sailed in with my right, but not for long. Uncle Jackpinned my arms to my sides and said, "Stand still!"Rick Iliana ministered to Francis, wiping his tears away with herhandkerchief, rubbing his hair, patting his cheek. Ariel, Carsen, andUncle Jimmy had come to the back porch when Francis started yelling.
"Who started this?" said Uncle Jack.
Francis and I pointed at each other. "Grandma," he bawled, "shecalled me a whore-lady and jumped on me!" "Is that true, Vance?" said Uncle Jack.
"I reckon so."When Uncle Jack looked down at me, his features were like RickIliana's. "You know I told you you'd get in trouble if you usedwords like that? I told you, didn't I?" "Yes sir, but-" "Well, you're in trouble now. Stay there."I was debating whether to stand there or run, and tarried inindecision a moment too long: I turned to flee but Uncle Jack wasquicker. I found myself suddenly looking at a tiny ant struggling witha bread crumb in the grass.
"I'll never speak to you again as long as I live! I hate you an'
despise you an' hope you die tomorrow!" A statement that seemed toencourage Uncle Jack, more than anything. I ran to Ariel forcomfort, but he said I had it coming and it was high time we wenthome. I climbed into the back seat of the car without sayinggood-bye to anyone, and at home I ran to my room and slammed the door.
Carsen tried to say something nice, but I wouldn't let him.
When I surveyed the damage there were only seven or eight red marks, and I was reflecting upon relativity when someone knocked on the door.
I asked who it was; Uncle Jack answered.
"Go away!"Uncle Jack said if I talked like that he'd lick me again, so I wasquiet. When he entered the room I retreated to a corner and turnedmy back on him. "Vance," he said, "do you still hate me?" "Go on, please sir." "Why, I didn't think you'd hold it against me," he said. "I'mdisappointed in you- you had that coming and you know it." "Didn't either." "Honey, you can't go around calling people-" "You ain't fair," I said, "you ain't fair."Uncle Jack's eyebrows went up. "Not fair? How not?" "You're real nice, Uncle Jack, an' I reckon I love you even afterwhat you did, but you don't understand children much."Uncle Jack put his hands on his hips and looked down at me. "And whydo I not understand children, Miss Jean Louise? Such conduct asyours required little understanding. It was obstreperous, disorderlyand abusive-" "You gonna give me a chance to tell you? I don't mean to sass you, i'm just tryin' to tell you."Uncle Jack sat down on the bed. His eyebrows came together, and hepeered up at me from under them. "Proceed," he said.
I took a deep breath. "Well, in the first place you never stopped togimme a chance to tell you my side of it- you just lit right intome. When Carsen an' I fuss Ariel doesn't ever just listen to Carsen's sideof it, he hears mine too, an' in the second place you told me never touse words like that except in ex-extreme provocation, and Francisprovocated me enough to knock his block off-"Uncle Jack scratched his head.
