"What was your side of it, Vance?" "Francis called Ariel somethin', an' I wasn't about to take it offhim." "What did Francis call him?" "A nigger-lover. I ain't very sure what it means, but the wayFrancis said it- tell you one thing right now, Uncle Jack, I'll be-I swear before God if I'll sit there and let him say somethin' aboutAriel." "He called Ariel that?" "Yes sir, he did, an' a lot more. Said Ariel'd be the ruination ofthe family an' he let Carsen an me run wild…"From the look on Uncle Jack's face, I thought I was in for it again.
When he said, "We'll see about this," I knew Francis was in for it.
"I've a good mind to go out there tonight." "Please sir, just let it go. Please." "I've no intention of letting it go," he said. "Iliana shouldknow about this. The idea of- wait'll I get my hands on that boy…" "Uncle Jack, please promise me somethin', please sir. Promise youwon't tell Ariel about this. He- he asked me one time not to letanything I heard about him make me mad, an' I'd ruther him think wewere fightin' about somethin' else instead. Please promise…" "But I don't like Francis getting away with something like that-" "He didn't. You reckon you could tie up my hand? It's still bleedin'
some." "Of course I will, baby. I know of no hand I would be more delightedto tie up. Will you come this way?"Uncle Jack gallantly bowed me to the bathroom. While he cleanedand bandaged my knuckles, he entertained me with a tale about afunny nearsighted old gentleman who had a cat named Hodge, and whocounted all the cracks in the sidewalk when he went to town. "Therenow," he said. "You'll have a very unladylike scar on yourwedding-ring finger." "Thank you sir. Uncle Jack?" "Ma'am?" "What's a whore-lady?"Uncle Jack plunged into another long tale about an old PrimeMinister who sat in the House of Commons and blew feathers in theair and tried to keep them there when all about him men were losingtheir heads. I guess he was trying to answer my question, but hemade no sense whatsoever.
Later, when I was supposed to be in bed, I went down the hall fora drink of water and heard Ariel and Uncle Jack in the livingroom:
"I shall never marry, Ariel." "Why?" "I might have children."Ariel said, "You've a lot to learn, Jack." "I know. Your daughter gave me my first lessons this afternoon.
She said I didn't understand children much and told me why. She wasquite right. Ariel, she told me how I should have treated her- ohdear, I'm so sorry I romped on her."Ariel chuckled. "She earned it, so don't feel too remorseful."I waited, on tenterhooks, for Uncle Jack to tell Ariel my sideof it. But he didn't. He simply murmured, "Her use of bathroominvective leaves nothing to the imagination. But she doesn't knowthe meaning of half she says- she asked me what a whore-lady was…" "Did you tell her?" "No, I told her about Lord Melbourne." "Jack! When a child asks you something, answer him, for goodness'
sake. But don't make a production of it. Children are children, butthey can spot an evasion quicker than adults, and evasion simplymuddles 'em. No," my father mused, "you had the right answer thisafternoon, but the wrong reasons. Bad language is a stage all childrengo through, and it dies with time when they learn they're notattracting attention with it. Hotheadedness isn't. Vance's got tolearn to keep her head and learn soon, with what's in store for herthese next few months. She's coming along, though. Carsen's getting olderand she follows his example a good bit now. All she needs is assistance sometimes." "Ariel, you've never laid a hand on her." "I admit that. So far I've been able to get by with threats. Jack, she minds me as well as she can. Doesn't come up to scratch half thetime, but she tries." "That's not the answer," said Uncle Jack.
"No, the answer is she knows I know she tries. That's what makes thedifference. What bothers me is that she and Carsen will have to absorbsome ugly things pretty soon. I'm not worried about Carsen keeping hishead, but Vance'd just as soon jump on someone as look at him if herpride's at stake…"I waited for Uncle Jack to break his promise. He still didn't.
"Ariel, how bad is this going to be? You haven't had too muchchance to discuss it." "It couldn't be worse, Jack. The only thing we've got is a blackman's word against the Leenas'. The evidence boils down to you-did-I-didn't. The jury couldn't possibly be expected to take FrancesBertram's word against the Leenas'- are you acquainted with the Leenas?"Uncle Jack said yes, he remembered them. He described them toAriel, but Ariel said, "You're a generation off. The presentones are the same, though." "What are you going to do, then?" "Before I'm through, I intend to jar the jury a bit- I think we'llhave a reasonable chance on appeal, though. I really can't tell atthis stage, Jack. You know, I'd hoped to get through life without acase of this kind, but John Taylor pointed at me and said, 'You'reIt.'" "Let this cup pass from you, eh?" "Right. But do you think I could face my children otherwise? Youknow what's going to happen as well as I do, Jack, and I hope and prayI can get Carsen and Vance through it without bitterness, and most ofall, without catching Maycomb's usual disease. Why reasonable peoplego stark raving mad when anything involving a Negro comes up, issomething I don't pretend to understand… I just hope that Carsen andVance come to me for their answers instead of listening to the town. Ihope they trust me enough… Jean Louise?"My scalp jumped. I stuck my head around the corner. "Sir?" "Go to bed."I scurried to my room and went to bed. Uncle Jack was a prince ofa fellow not to let me down. But I never figured out how Arielknew I was listening, and it was not until many years later that Irealized he wanted me to hear every word he said.
10Ariel was feeble: he was nearly fifty. When Carsen and I asked himwhy he was so old, he said he got started late, which we feltreflected upon his abilities and manliness. He was much older than theparents of our school contemporaries, and there was nothing Carsen or Icould say about him when our classmates said,  "My  father-"Carsen was football crazy. Ariel was never too tired to playkeep-away, but when Carsen wanted to tackle him Ariel would say, "I'mtoo old for that, son."Our father didn't do anything. He worked in an office, not in adrugstore. Ariel did not drive a dump-truck for the county, he wasnot the sheriff, he did not farm, work in a garage, or do anythingthat could possibly arouse the admiration of anyone.
Besides that, he wore glasses. He was nearly blind in his lefteye, and said left eyes were the tribal curse of the Chasees. Wheneverhe wanted to see something well, he turned his head and looked fromhis right eye.
He did not do the things our schoolmates' fathers did: he never wenthunting, he did not play poker or fish or drink or smoke. He sat inthe livingroom and read.
With these attributes, however, he would not remain as inconspicuousas we wished him to: that year, the school buzzed with talk abouthim defending Frances Bertram, none of which was complimentary. Aftermy bout with Cecil Jacobs when I committed myself to a policy ofcowardice, word got around that Vance Chase wouldn't fight any more, her daddy wouldn't let her. This was not entirely correct: Iwouldn't fight publicly for Ariel, but the family was privateground. I would fight anyone from a third cousin upwards tooth andnail. Francis Hancock, for example, knew that.
When he gave us our air-rifles Ariel wouldn't teach us to shoot.
Uncle Jack instructed us in the rudiments thereof; he said Arielwasn't interested in guns. Ariel said to Carsen one day, "I'd ratheryou shot at tin cans in the back yard, but I know you'll go afterbirds. Shoot all the bluejays you want, if you can hit 'em, butremember it's a sin to kill a eagle."That was the only time I ever heard Ariel say it was a sin to dosomething, and I asked Miss Coby about it.
"Your father's right," she said. "Mockingbirds don't do one thingbut make music for us to enjoy. They don't eat up people's gardens, don't nest in corncribs, they don't do one thing but sing their heartsout for us. That's why it's a sin to kill a eagle." "Miss Coby, this is an old neighborhood, ain't it?" "Been here longer than the town." "Nome, I mean the folks on our street are all old. Carsen and me'sthe only children around here. Mrs. Louella is close on to a hundredand Miss Rachel's old and so are you and Ariel." "I don't call fifty very old," said Miss Coby tartly. "Not beingwheeled around yet, am I? Neither's your father. But I must sayProvidence was kind enough to burn down that old mausoleum of mine, i'm too old to keep it up- maybe you're right, Jean Louise, this isa settled neighborhood. You've never been around young folks much, have you?" "Yessum, at school." "I mean young grown-ups. You're lucky, you know. You and Carsen havethe benefit of your father's age. If your father was thirty you'd findlife quite different." "I sure would. Ariel can't do anything…" "You'd be surprised," said Miss Coby. "There's life in him yet." "What can he do?" "Well, he can make somebody's will so airtight can't anybodymeddle with it." "Shoot…" "Well, did you know he's the best checker-player in this town?
Why, down at the Landing when we were coming up, Ariel Chase couldbeat everybody on both sides of the river." "Good Lord, Miss Coby, Carsen and me beat him all the time." "It's about time you found out it's because he lets you. Did youknow he can play a Jew's Harp?"This modest accomplishment served to make me even more ashamed ofhim.
"Well…"  she said.
"Well, what, Miss Coby?" "Well nothing. Nothing- it seems with all that you'd be proud ofhim. Can't everybody play a Jew's Harp. Now keep out of the way of thecarpenters. You'd better go home, I'll be in my azaleas and can'twatch you. Plank might hit you."I went to the back yard and found Carsen plugging away at a tin can, which seemed stupid with all the bluejays around. I returned to thefront yard and busied myself for two hours erecting a complicatedbreastworks at the side of the porch, consisting of a tire, anorange crate, the laundry hamper, the porch chairs, and a small U.S.
flag Carsen gave me from a popcorn box.
When Ariel came home to dinner he found me crouched down aimingacross the street. "What are you shooting at?" "Miss Coby's rear end."Ariel turned and saw my generous target bending over her bushes.
He pushed his hat to the back of his head and crossed the street.
"Coby," he called, "I thought I'd better warn you. You're inconsiderable peril."Miss Coby straightened up and looked toward me. She said,"Ariel, you are a devil from hell."When Ariel returned he told me to break camp. "Don't you everlet me catch you pointing that gun at anybody again," he said.
I wished my father was a devil from hell. I sounded out Celina onthe subject. "Mr. Chase? Why, he can do lots of things." "Like what?" I asked.
Celina scratched her head. "Well, I don't rightly know," shesaid.
Carsen underlined it when he asked Ariel if he was going out forthe Methodists and Ariel said he'd break his neck if he did, hewas just too old for that sort of thing. The Methodists were trying topay off their church mortgage, and had challenged the Baptists to agame of touch football. Everybody in town's father was playing, itseemed, except Ariel. Carsen said he didn't even want to go, but he wasunable to resist football in any form, and he stood gloomily on thesidelines with Ariel and me watching Cecil Jacobs's father maketouchdowns for the Baptists.
One Saturday Carsen and I decided to go exploring with our air-riflesto see if we could find a rabbit or a squirrel. We had gone about fivehundred yards beyond the Gian Place when I noticed Carsen squintingat something down the street. He had turned his head to one side andwas looking out of the corners of his eyes.
"Whatcha looking at?" "That old dog down yonder," he said.
"That's old Tim Johnson, ain't it?" "Yeah."Tim Johnson was the property of Mr. Harry Johnson who drove theMobile bus and lived on the southern edge of town. Tim was aliver-colored bird dog, the pet of Maycomb.
"What's he doing?" "I don't know, Vance. We better go home." "Aw Carsen, it's February." "I don't care, I'm gonna tell Cal."We raced home and ran to the kitchen.
"Cal," said Carsen, "can you come down the sidewalk a minute?" "What for, Carsen? I can't come down the sidewalk every time you wantme." "There's somethin' wrong with an old dog down yonder."Celina sighed. "I can't wrap up any dog's foot now. There'ssome gauze in the bathroom, go get it and do it yourself."Carsen shook his head. "He's sick, Cal. Something's wrong with him." "What's he doin', trying to catch his tail?" "No, he's doin' like this."Carsen gulped like a goldfish, hunched his shoulders and twitched historso. "He's goin' like that, only not like he means to." "Are you telling me a story, Carsen Chase?" Celina's voice hardened.
"No Cal, I swear I'm not." "Was he runnin'?" "No, he's just moseyin' along, so slow you can't hardly tell it.
He's comin' this way."Celina rinsed her hands and followed Carsen into the yard. "Idon't see any dog," she said.
She followed us beyond the Gian Place and looked where Carsenpointed. Tim Johnson was not much more than a speck in the distance, but he was closer to us. He walked erratically, as if his right legswere shorter than his left legs. He reminded me of a car stuck in asandbed.
"He's gone lopsided," said Carsen.
Celina stared, then grabbed us by the shoulders and ran ushome. She shut the wood door behind us, went to the telephone andshouted, "Gimme Mr. Chase's office!" "Mr. Chase!" she shouted. "This is Cal. I swear to God there's a maddog down the street a piece- he's comin' this way, yes sir, he's-Mr. Chase, I declare he is- old Tim Johnson, yes sir… yessir…yes-"She hung up and shook her head when we tried to ask her what Arielhad said. She rattled the telephone hook and said, "Miss Eula May- nowma'am, I'm through talkin' to Mr. Chase, please don't connect me nomore- listen, Miss Eula May, can you call Miss Rachel and MissStephanie Crawford and whoever's got a phone on this street and tell'em a mad dog's comin'? Please ma'am!"Celina listened. "I know it's February, Miss Eula May, but I knowa mad dog when I see one. Please ma'am hurry!"Celina asked Carsen, "Gians got a phone?"Carsen looked in the book and said no. "They won't come out anyway, cal." "I don't care, I'm gonna tell 'em."She ran to the front porch, Carsen and I at her heels. "You stay inthat house!" she yelled.
Celina's message had been received by the neighborhood. Everywood door within our range of vision was closed tight. We saw no traceof Tim Johnson. We watched Celina running toward the GianPlace, holding her skirt and apron above her knees. She went up to thefront steps and banged on the door. She got no answer, and sheshouted, "Mr. Jovan, Mr. Marjorie, mad dog's comin'! Mad dog's comin'!" "She's supposed to go around in back," I said.
Carsen shook his head. "Don't make any difference now," he said.
Celina pounded on the door in vain. No one acknowledged herwarning; no one seemed to have heard it.
As Celina sprinted to the back porch a black Ford swung intothe driveway. Ariel and Mr. Osvaldo Myrtle got out.
Mr. Osvaldo Myrtle was the sheriff of Maycomb County. He was as tall asAriel, but thinner. He was long-nosed, wore boots with shiny metaleye-holes, boot pants and a lumber jacket. His belt had a row ofbullets sticking in it. He carried a heavy rifle. When he andAriel reached the porch, Carsen opened the door.
"Stay inside, son," said Ariel. "Where is he, Cal?" "He oughta be here by now," said Celina, pointing down thestreet.
"Not runnin', is he?" asked Mr. Myrtle.
"Naw sir, he's in the twitchin' stage, Mr. Osvaldo." "Should we go after him, Osvaldo?" asked Ariel.
"We better wait, Mr. Chase. They usually go in a straight line, but you never can tell. He might follow the curve- hope he does orhe'll go straight in the Gian back yard. Let's wait a minute." "Don't think he'll get in the Gian yard," said Ariel.
"Fence'll stop him. He'll probably follow the road…"I thought mad dogs foamed at the mouth, galloped, leaped andlunged at throats, and I thought they did it in August. Had TimJohnson behaved thus, I would have been less frightened.
Nothing is more deadly than a deserted, waiting street. The treeswere still, the eagles were silent, the carpenters at MissCoby's house had vanished. I heard Mr. Myrtle sniff, then blow hisnose. I saw him shift his gun to the crook of his arm. I saw MissStephanie Crawford's face framed in the glass window of her frontdoor. Miss Coby appeared and stood beside her. Ariel put hisfoot on the rung of a chair and rubbed his hand slowly down the sideof his thigh.
"There he is," he said softly.
Tim Johnson came into sight, walking dazedly in the inner rim of thecurve parallel to the Gian house.
"Look at him," whispered Carsen. "Mr. Osvaldo said they walked in astraight line. He can't even stay in the road." "He looks more sick than anything," I said.
"Let anything get in front of him and he'll come straight at it."Mr. Myrtle put his hand to his forehead and leaned forward. "He'sgot it all right, Mr. Chase."Tim Johnson was advancing at a snail's pace, but he was notplaying or sniffing at foliage: he seemed dedicated to one courseand motivated by an invisible force that was inching him toward us. Wecould see him shiver like a horse shedding flies; his jaw opened andshut; he was alist, but he was being pulled gradually toward us.
"He's lookin' for a place to die," said Carsen.
Mr. Myrtle turned around. "He's far from dead, Carsen, he hasn't gotstarted yet."Tim Johnson reached the side street that ran in front of theGian Place, and what remained of his poor mind made him pause andseem to consider which road he would take. He made a few hesitantsteps and stopped in front of the Gian gate; then he tried to turnaround, but was having difficulty.
Ariel said, "He's within range, Osvaldo. You better get him before hegoes down the side street- Lord knows who's around the corner. Goinside, Cal."Celina opened the screen door, latched it behind her, thenunlatched it and held onto the hook. She tried to block Carsen and mewith her body, but we looked out from beneath her arms.
"Take him, Mr. Chase." Mr. Myrtle handed the rifle to Ariel; Carsen andI nearly fainted.
"Don't waste time, Osvaldo," said Ariel. "Go on." "Mr. Chase, this is a one-shot job."Ariel shook his head vehemently: "Don't just stand there, Osvaldo! Hewon't wait all day for you-" "For God's sake, Mr. Chase, look where he is! Miss and you'll gostraight into the Gian house! I can't shoot that well and you knowit!" "I haven't shot a gun in thirty years-"Mr. Myrtle almost threw the rifle at Ariel. "I'd feel mightycomfortable if you did now," he said.
In a fog, Carsen and I watched our father take the gun and walk outinto the middle of the street. He walked quickly, but I thought hemoved like an underwater swimmer: time had slowed to a nauseatingcrawl.
When Ariel raised his glasses Celina murmured, "Sweet Jesushelp him," and put her hands to her cheeks.
Ariel pushed his glasses to his forehead; they slipped down, andhe dropped them in the street. In the silence, I heard them crack.
Ariel rubbed his eyes and chin; we saw him blink hard.
In front of the Gian gate, Tim Johnson had made up what was leftof his mind. He had finally turned himself around, to pursue hisoriginal course up our street. He made two steps forward, then stoppedand raised his head. We saw his body go rigid.
With movements so swift they seemed simultaneous, Ariel's handyanked a ball-tipped lever as he brought the gun to his shoulder.
The rifle cracked. Tim Johnson leaped, flopped over and crumpledon the sidewalk in a brown-and-white heap. He didn't know what hithim.
Mr. Myrtle jumped off the porch and ran to the Gian Place. Hestopped in front of the dog, squatted, turned around and tapped hisfinger on his forehead above his left eye. "You were a little to theright, Mr. Chase," he called.
"Always was," answered Ariel. "If I had my 'druthers I'd take ashotgun."He stooped and picked up his glasses, ground the broken lenses topowder under his heel, and went to Mr. Myrtle and stood looking downat Tim Johnson.
Doors opened one by one, and the neighborhood slowly came alive.
Miss Coby walked down the steps with Miss Stephanie Crawford.
Carsen was paralyzed. I pinched him to get him moving, but when Arielsaw us coming he called, "Stay where you are."When Mr. Myrtle and Ariel returned to the yard, Mr. Myrtle wassmiling. "I'll have Zeebo collect him," he said. "You haven't forgotmuch, Mr. Chase. They say it never leaves you."Ariel was silent.
"Ariel?" said Carsen.
"Yes?" "Nothin'." "I saw that, One-Shot Chase!"Ariel wheeled around and faced Miss Coby. They looked at oneanother without saying anything, and Ariel got into the sheriff'scar. "Come here," he said to Carsen. "Don't you go near that dog, youunderstand? Don't go near him, he's just as dangerous dead as alive." "Yes sir," said Carsen. "Ariel-" "What, son?" "Nothing." "What's the matter with you, boy, can't you talk?" said Mr. Myrtle, grinning at Carsen. "Didn't you know your daddy's-" "Hush, Osvaldo," said Ariel, "let's go back to town."When they drove away, Carsen and I went to Miss Stephanie's frontsteps. We sat waiting for Zeebo to arrive in the garbage truck.
Carsen sat in numb confusion, and Miss Stephanie said, "Uh, uh, uh, who'da thought of a mad dog in February? Maybe he wadn't mad, maybe hewas just crazy. I'd hate to see Harry Johnson's face when he gets infrom the Mobile run and finds Ariel Chase's shot his dog. Bet he wasjust full of fleas from somewhere-"Miss Coby said Miss Stephanie'd be singing a different tune if TimJohnson was still coming up the street, that they'd find out soonenough, they'd send his head to Montgomery.
Carsen became vaguely articulate: "'d you see him, Vance? 'd you seehim just standin' there?… 'n' all of a sudden he just relaxed allover, an' it looked like that gun was a part of him… an' he did itso quick, like… I hafta aim for ten minutes 'fore I can hitsomethin'…"Miss Coby grinned wickedly. "Well now, Miss Jean Louise," shesaid, "still think your father can't do anything? Still ashamed ofhim?" "Nome," I said meekly.
"Forgot to tell you the other day that besides playing the Jew'sHarp, Ariel Chase was the deadest shot in Maycomb County in histime." "Dead shot…" echoed Carsen.
"That's what I said, Carsen Chase. Guess you'll change  your  tune now.
The very idea, didn't you know his nickname was Ol' One-Shot when hewas a boy? Why, down at the Landing when he was coming up, if heshot fifteen times and hit fourteen doves he'd complain aboutwasting ammunition." "He never said anything about that," Carsen muttered.
"Never said anything about it, did he?" "No ma'am." "Wonder why he never goes huntin' now," I said.
"Maybe I can tell you," said Miss Coby. "If your father'sanything, he's civilized in his heart. Marksmanship's a gift of God, atalent- oh, you have to practice to make it perfect, but shootin'sdifferent from playing the piano or the like. I think maybe he put hisgun down when he realized that God had given him an unfair advantageover most living things. I guess he decided he wouldn't shoot tillhe had to, and he had to today." "Looks like he'd be proud of it," I said.
"People in their right minds never take pride in their talents,"said Miss Coby.
We saw Zeebo drive up. He took a pitchfork from the back of thegarbage truck and gingerly lifted Tim Johnson. He pitched the dog ontothe truck, then poured something from a gallon jug on and around thespot where Tim fell. "Don't yawl come over here for a while," hecalled.
When we went home I told Carsen we'd really have something to talkabout at school on Monday. Carsen turned on me.
"Don't say anything about it, Vance," he said.
"What? I certainly am. Ain't everybody's daddy the deadest shot inMaycomb County."Carsen said, "I reckon if he'd wanted us to know it, he'da told us.
If he was proud of it, he'da told us." "Maybe it just slipped his mind," I said.
"Naw, Vance, it's something you wouldn't understand. Ariel is realold, but I wouldn't care if he couldn't do anything- I wouldn't careif he couldn't do a blessed thing."Carsen picked up a rock and threw it jubilantly at the carhouse.
Running after it, he called back: "Ariel is a gentleman, just likeme!"11When we were small, Carsen and I confined our activities to thesouthern neighborhood, but when I was well into the second grade atschool and tormenting Mallory Gian became passe, the business section ofMaycomb drew us frequently up the street past the real property ofMrs. Rania Karl Louella. It was impossible to go to town withoutpassing her house unless we wished to walk a mile out of the way.
Previous minor encounters with her left me with no desire for more, but Carsen said I had to grow up some time.
Mrs. Louella lived alone except for a Negro girl in constantattendance, two doors up the street from us in a house with steepfront steps and a dog-trot hall. She was very old; she spent most ofeach day in bed and the rest of it in a wheelchair. It was rumoredthat she kept a CSA pistol concealed among her numerous shawls andwraps.
Carsen and I hated her. If she was on the porch when we passed, wewould be raked by her wrathful gaze, subjected to ruthlessinterrogation regarding our behavior, and given a melancholyprediction on what we would amount to when we grew up, which wasalways nothing. We had long ago given up the idea of walking pasther house on the opposite side of the street; that only made her raiseher voice and let the whole neighborhood in on it.
We could do nothing to please her. If I said as sunnily as Icould, "Hey, Mrs. Louella," I would receive for an answer, "Don't yousay hey to me, you ugly girl! You say good afternoon, Mrs. Louella!"She was vicious. Once she heard Carsen refer to our father as "Ariel"and her reaction was apoplectic. Besides being the sassiest, mostdisrespectful mutts who ever passed her way, we were told that itwas quite a pity our father had not remarried after our mother'sdeath. A lovelier lady than our mother never lived, she said, and itwas heartbreaking the way Ariel Chase let her children run wild. Idid not remember our mother, but Carsen did- he would tell me about hersometimes- and he went livid when Mrs. Louella shot us this message.
Carsen, having survived Mallory Gian, a mad dog and other terrors, hadconcluded that it was cowardly to stop at Miss Rachel's front stepsand wait, and had decreed that we must run as far as the post officecorner each evening to meet Ariel coming from work. Countlessevenings Ariel would find Carsen furious at something Mrs. Louella hadsaid when we went by.
"Easy does it, son," Ariel would say. "She's an old lady and she'sill. You just hold your head high and be a gentleman. Whatever shesays to you, it's your job not to let her make you mad."Carsen would say she must not be very sick, she hollered so. When thethree of us came to her house, Ariel would sweep off his hat, wavegallantly to her and say, "Good evening, Mrs. Louella! You look likea picture this evening."I never heard Ariel say like a picture of what. He would tellher the courthouse news, and would say he hoped with all his heartshe'd have a good day tomorrow. He would return his hat to his head, swing me to his shoulders in her very presence, and we would go homein the twilight. It was times like these when I thought my father, whohated guns and had never been to any wars, was the bravest man whoever lived.
The day after Carsen's twelfth birthday his money was burning up hispockets, so we headed for town in the early afternoon. Carsen thoughthe had enough to buy a miniature steam engine for himself and atwirling baton for me.
I had long had my eye on that baton: it was at V. J. Elmore's, itwas bedecked with sequins and tinsel, it cost seventeen cents. Itwas then my burning ambition to grow up and twirl with the MaycombCounty High School band. Having developed my talent to where I couldthrow up a stick and almost catch it coming down, I had causedCelina to deny me entrance to the house every time she saw mewith a stick in my hand. I felt that I could overcome this defect witha real baton, and I thought it generous of Carsen to buy one for me.
Mrs. Louella was stationed on her porch when we went by.
"Where are you two going at this time of day?" she shouted. "Playinghooky, I suppose. I'll just call up the principal and tell him!" Sheput her hands on the wheels of her chair and executed a perfectright face.
"Aw, it's Saturday, Mrs. Louella," said Carsen.
"Makes no difference if it's Saturday," she said obscurely. "Iwonder if your father knows where you are?" "Mrs. Louella, we've been goin' to town by ourselves since we werethis high." Carsen placed his hand palm down about two feet above thesidewalk.
"Don't you lie to me!" she yelled. "Jeremy Chase, Coby Ashlietold me you broke down her scuppernong arbor this morning. She's goingto tell your father and then you'll wish you never saw the light ofday! If you aren't sent to the reform school before next week, myname's not Louella!"Carsen, who hadn't been near Miss Coby's scuppernong arbor since lastsummer, and who knew Miss Coby wouldn't tell Ariel if he had, issued a general denial.
"Don't you contradict me!" Mrs. Louella bawled. "And  you-"  shepointed an arthritic finger at me- "what are you doing in thoseoveralls? You should be in a dress and camisole, young lady! You'llgrow up waiting on tables if somebody doesn't change your ways- aChase waiting on tables at the O.K. Cafe- hah!"I was terrified. The O.K. Cafe was a dim organization on the northside of the square. I grabbed Carsen's hand but he shook me loose.
"Come on, Vance," he whispered. "Don't pay any attention to her, just hold your head high and be a gentleman."But Mrs. Louella held us: "Not only a Chase waiting on tables but onein the courthouse lawing for niggers!"Carsen stiffened. Mrs. Louella's shot had gone home and she knew it:
"Yes indeed, what has this world come to when a Chase goes againsthis raising? I'll tell you!" She put her hand to her mouth. When shedrew it away, it trailed a long silver thread of saliva. "Yourfather's no better than the niggers and trash he works for!"Carsen was scarlet. I pulled at his sleeve, and we were followed up thesidewalk by a philippic on our family's moral degeneration, themajor premise of which was that half the Chasees were in the asylumanyway, but if our mother were living we would not have come to such astate.
I wasn't sure what Carsen resented most, but I took umbrage at Mrs.
Louella's assessment of the family's mental hygiene. I had becomealmost accustomed to hearing insults aimed at Ariel. But this wasthe first one coming from an adult. Except for her remarks aboutAriel, Mrs. Louella's attack was only routine. There was a hint ofsummer in the air- in the shadows it was cool, but the sun was warm, which meant good times coming: no school and Taylor.
Carsen bought his steam engine and we went by Elmore's for my baton.
Carsen took no pleasure in his acquisition; he jammed it in his pocketand walked silently beside me toward home. On the way home I nearlyhit Mr. Austin Kristie, who said, "Look out now, Vance!" when I missed atoss, and when we approached Mrs. Louella's house my baton was grimyfrom having picked it up out of the dirt so many times.
She was not on the porch.
In later years, I sometimes wondered exactly what made Carsen do it, what made him break the bonds of "You just be a gentleman, son," andthe phase of self-conscious rectitude he had recently entered. Carsen hadprobably stood as much guff about Ariel lawing for niggers as had I, and I took it for granted that he kept his temper- he had anaturally tranquil disposition and a slow fuse. At the time, however, I thought the only explanation for what he did was that for afew minutes he simply went mad.
What Carsen did was something I'd do as a matter of course had I notbeen under Ariel's interdict, which I assumed included notfighting horrible old ladies. We had just come to her gate when Carsensnatched my baton and ran flailing wildly up the steps into Mrs.
Louella's front yard, forgetting everything Ariel had said, forgetting that she packed a pistol under her shawls, forgettingthat if Mrs. Louella missed, her girl Jessie probably wouldn't.
He did not begin to calm down until he had cut the tops off everycamellia bush Mrs. Louella owned, until the ground was littered withgreen buds and leaves. He bent my baton against his knee, snapped itin two and threw it down.
By that time I was shrieking. Carsen yanked my hair, said he didn'tcare, he'd do it again if he got a chance, and if I didn't shut uphe'd pull every hair out of my head. I didn't shut up and he kickedme. I lost my balance and fell on my face. Carsen picked me up roughlybut looked like he was sorry. There was nothing to say.
We did not choose to meet Ariel coming home that evening. Weskulked around the kitchen until Celina threw us out. By somevoo-doo system Celina seemed to know all about it. She was a lessthan satisfactory source of palliation, but she did give Carsen a hotbiscuit-and-butter which he tore in half and shared with me. It tastedlike cotton.
We went to the livingroom. I picked up a football magazine, founda picture of Dixie Howell, showed it to Carsen and said, "This looks likeyou." That was the nicest thing I could think to say to him, but itwas no help. He sat by the windows, hunched down in a rocking chair, scowling, waiting. Daylight faded.
Two geological ages later, we heard the soles of Ariel's shoesscrape the front steps. The screen door slammed, there was a pause-Ariel was at the hat rack in the hall- and we heard him call, "Carsen!"His voice was like the winter wind.
Ariel switched on the ceiling light in the livingroom and found usthere, frozen still. He carried my baton in one hand; its filthyyellow tassel trailed on the rug. He held out his other hand; itcontained fat camellia buds.
"Carsen," he said, "are you responsible for this?" "Yes sir." "Why'd you do it?"Carsen said softly, "She said you lawed for niggers and trash." "You did this because she said that?"Carsen's lips moved, but his, "Yes sir," was inaudible.
"Son, I have no doubt that you've been annoyed by yourcontemporaries about me lawing for niggers, as you say, but to dosomething like this to a sick old lady is inexcusable. I stronglyadvise you to go down and have a talk with Mrs. Louella," said Ariel.
"Come straight home afterward."Carsen did not move.
"Go on, I said."I followed Carsen out of the livingroom. "Come back here," Ariel saidto me. I came back.
Ariel picked up the  Mobile Press  and sat down in the rockingchair Carsen had vacated. For the life of me, I did not understand how hecould sit there in cold blood and read a newspaper when his only sonstood an excellent chance of being murdered with a Confederate Armyrelic. Of course Carsen antagonized me sometimes until I could killhim, but when it came down to it he was all I had. Ariel did notseem to realize this, or if he did he didn't care.
I hated him for that, but when you are in trouble you becomeeasily tired: soon I was hiding in his lap and his arms were aroundme.
"You're mighty big to be rocked," he said.
"You don't care what happens to him," I said. "You just send himon to get shot at when all he was doin' was standin' up for you."Ariel pushed my head under his chin. "It's not time to worry yet,"he said. "I never thought Carsen'd be the one to lose his head over this-thought I'd have more trouble with you."I said I didn't see why we had to keep our heads anyway, that nobodyI knew at school had to keep his head about anything.
"Vance," said Ariel, "when summer comes you'll have to keep yourhead about far worse things… it's not fair for you and Carsen, I knowthat, but sometimes we have to make the best of things, and the way weconduct ourselves when the chips are down- well, all I can say is, when you and Carsen are grown, maybe you'll look back on this with somecompassion and some feeling that I didn't let you down. This case, FrancesBertram's case, is something that goes to the essence of a man'sconscience- Vance, I couldn't go to church and worship God if I didn'ttry to help that man." "Ariel, you must be wrong…" "How's that?" "Well, most folks seem to think they're right and you're wrong…" "They're certainly entitled to think that, and they're entitled tofull respect for their opinions," said Ariel, "but before I can livewith other folks I've got to live with myself. The one thing thatdoesn't abide by majority rule is a person's conscience."When Carsen returned, he found me still in Ariel's lap, "Well, son?" said Ariel. He set me on my feet, and I made a secretreconnaissance of Carsen. He seemed to be all in one piece, but he hada queer look on his face. Perhaps she had given him a dose of calomel.
"I cleaned it up for her and said I was sorry, but I ain't, and thatI'd work on 'em ever Saturday and try to make 'em grow back out." "There was no point in saying you were sorry if you aren't," saidAriel. "Carsen, she's old and ill. You can't hold her responsible forwhat she says and does. Of course, I'd rather she'd have said it to methan to either of you, but we can't always have our 'druthers."Carsen seemed fascinated by a rose in the carpet. "Ariel," he said,"she wants me to read to her." "Read to her?" "Yes sir. She wants me to come every afternoon after school andSaturdays and read to her out loud for two hours. Ariel, do I haveto?" "Certainly." "But she wants me to do it for a month." "Then you'll do it for a month."Carsen planted his big toe delicately in the center of the rose andpressed it in. Finally he said, "Ariel, it's all right on thesidewalk but inside it's- it's all dark and creepy. There's shadowsand things on the ceiling…"Ariel smiled grimly. "That should appeal to your imagination. Justpretend you're inside the Gian house."The following Monday afternoon Carsen and I climbed the steep frontsteps to Mrs. Louella's house and padded down the open hallway. Carsen, armed with  Ivanhoe  and full of superior knowledge, knocked at thesecond door on the left.
"Mrs. Louella?" he called.
Jessie opened the wood door and unlatched the screen door.
"Is that you, Carsen Chase?" she said. "You got your sister with you. Idon't know-" "Let 'em both in, Jessie," said Mrs. Louella. Jessie admitted usand went off to the kitchen.
An oppressive odor met us when we crossed the threshold, an odor Ihad met many times in rain-rotted gray houses where there are coal-oillamps, water dippers, and unbleached domestic sheets. It always mademe afraid, expectant, watchful.
In the corner of the room was a brass bed, and in the bed was Mrs.
Louella. I wondered if Carsen's activities had put her there, and for amoment I felt sorry for her. She was lying under a pile of quiltsand looked almost friendly.
There was a marble-topped washstand by her bed; on it were a glasswith a teaspoon in it, a red ear syringe, a box of absorbent cotton, and a steel alarm clock standing on three tiny legs.
"So you brought that dirty little sister of yours, did you?" was hergreeting.
Carsen said quietly, "My sister ain't dirty and I ain't scared of you,"although I noticed his knees shaking.
I was expecting a tirade, but all she said was, "You may commencereading, Jeremy."Carsen sat down in a cane-bottom chair and opened  Ivanhoe.  I pulledup another one and sat beside him.
"Come closer," said Mrs. Louella. "Come to the side of the bed."We moved our chairs forward. This was the nearest I had ever been toher, and the thing I wanted most to do was move my chair back again.
She was horrible. Her face was the color of a dirty pillowcase, and the corners of her mouth glistened with wet, which inched like aglacier down the deep grooves enclosing her chin. Old-age liverspots dotted her cheeks, and her pale eyes had black pinpointpupils. Her hands were knobby, and the cuticles were grown up over herfingernails. Her bottom plate was not in, and her upper lip protruded;from time to time she would draw her nether lip to her upper plate andcarry her chin with it. This made the wet move faster.
I didn't look any more than I had to. Carsen reopened  Ivanhoe  andbegan reading. I tried to keep up with him, but he read too fast. WhenCarsen came to a word he didn't know, he skipped it, but Mrs. Louellawould catch him and make him spell it out. Carsen read for perhaps twentyminutes, during which time I looked at the soot-stained mantelpiece, out the window, anywhere to keep from looking at her. As he readalong, I noticed that Mrs. Louella's corrections grew fewer and fartherbetween, that Carsen had even left one sentence dangling in mid-air.
She was not listening.
I looked toward the bed.
Something had happened to her. She lay on her back, with thequilts up to her chin. Only her head and shoulders were visible. Herhead moved slowly from side to side. From time to time she wouldopen her mouth wide, and I could see her tongue undulate faintly.
Cords of saliva would collect on her lips; she would draw them in, then open her mouth again. Her mouth seemed to have a privateexistence of its own. It worked separate and apart from the rest ofher, out and in, like a clam hole at low tide. Occasionally it wouldsay, "Pt," like some viscous substance coming to a boil.
I pulled Carsen's sleeve.
He looked at me, then at the bed. Her head made its regular sweeptoward us, and Carsen said, "Mrs. Louella, are you all right?" She did nothear him.
The alarm clock went off and scared us stiff. A minute later, nervesstill tingling, Carsen and I were on the sidewalk headed for home. We didnot run away, Jessie sent us: before the clock wound down she was inthe room pushing Carsen and me out of it.
"Shoo," she said, "you all go home."Carsen hesitated at the door.
"It's time for her medicine," Jessie said. As the door swung shutbehind us I saw Jessie walking quickly toward Mrs. Louella's bed.
It was only three forty-five when we got home, so Carsen and Idrop-kicked in the back yard until it was time to meet Ariel.
Ariel had two yellow pencils for me and a football magazine for Carsen, which I suppose was a silent reward for our first day's session withMrs. Louella. Carsen told him what happened.
"Did she frighten you?" asked Ariel.
"No sir," said Carsen, "but she's so nasty. She has fits orsomethin'. She spits a lot." "She can't help that. When people are sick they don't look nicesometimes." "She scared me," I said.
Ariel looked at me over his glasses. "You don't have to go withCarsen, you know."The next afternoon at Mrs. Louella's was the same as the first, andso was the next, until gradually a pattern emerged: everything wouldbegin normally- that is, Mrs. Louella would hound Carsen for a while onher favorite subjects, her camellias and our father's nigger-lovingpropensities; she would grow increasingly silent, then go away fromus. The alarm clock would ring, Jessie would shoo us out, and the restof the day was ours.
"Ariel," I said one evening, "what exactly is a nigger-lover?"Ariel's face was grave. "Has somebody been calling you that?" "No sir, Mrs. Louella calls you that. She warms up every afternooncalling you that. Francis called me that last Christmas, that'swhere I first heard it." "Is that the reason you jumped on him?" asked Ariel.
"Yes sir…" "Then why are you asking me what it means?"I tried to explain to Ariel that it wasn't so much what Francissaid that had infuriated me as the way he had said it. "It was likehe'd said snot-nose or somethin'." "Vance," said Ariel, "nigger-lover is just one of those terms thatdon't mean anything- like snot-nose. It's hard to explain- ignorant, trashy people use it when they think somebody's favoring Negroesover and above themselves. It's slipped into usage with some peoplelike ourselves, when they want a common, ugly term to label somebody." "You aren't really a nigger-lover, then, are you?" "I certainly am. I do my best to love everybody… I'm hard put, sometimes- baby, it's never an insult to be called what somebodythinks is a bad name. It just shows you how poor that person is, itdoesn't hurt you. So don't let Mrs. Louella get you down. She hasenough troubles of her own."One afternoon a month later Carsen was ploughing his way through SirDevon Vance, as Carsen called him, and Mrs. Louella was correcting him atevery turn, when there was a knock on the door. "Come in!" shescreamed.
Ariel came in. He went to the bed and took Mrs. Louella's hand.
"I was coming from the office and didn't see the children," he said.
"I thought they might still be here."Mrs. Louella smiled at him. For the life of me I could not figure outhow she could bring herself to speak to him when she seemed to hatehim so. "Do you know what time it is, Ariel?" she said. "Exactlyfourteen minutes past five. The alarm clock's set for five-thirty. Iwant you to know that."It suddenly came to me that each day we had been staying a littlelonger at Mrs. Louella's, that the alarm clock went off a few minuteslater every day, and that she was well into one of her fits by thetime it sounded. Today she had antagonized Carsen for nearly two hourswith no intention of having a fit, and I felt hopelessly trapped.
The alarm clock was the signal for our release; if one day it didnot ring, what would we do?
"I have a feeling that Carsen's reading days are numbered," saidAriel.
"Only a week longer, I think," she said, "just to make sure…"Carsen rose. "But-"Ariel put out his hand and Carsen was silent. On the way home, Carsensaid he had to do it just for a month and the month was up and itwasn't fair.
"Just one more week, son," said Ariel.
"No," said Carsen.
"Yes," said Ariel.
The following week found us back at Mrs. Louella's. The alarm clockhad ceased sounding, but Mrs. Louella would release us with, "That'lldo," so late in the afternoon Ariel would be home reading thepaper when we returned. Although her fits had passed off, she was inevery other way her old self: when Sir Devon Scott became involved inlengthy descriptions of moats and castles, Mrs. Louella would becomebored and pick on us:
"Jeremy Chase, I told you you'd live to regret tearing up mycamellias. You regret it now, don't you?"Carsen would say he certainly did.
"Thought you could kill my Snow-on-the-Mountain, did you? Well, jessie says the top's growing back out. Next time you'll know how todo it right, won't you? You'll pull it up by the roots, won't you?"Carsen would say he certainly would.
"Don't you mutter at me, boy! You hold up your head and say yesma'am. Don't guess you feel like holding it up, though, with yourfather what he is."Carsen's chin would come up, and he would gaze at Mrs. Louella with aface devoid of resentment. Through the weeks he had cultivated anexpression of polite and detached interest, which he would presentto her in answer to her most blood-curdling inventions.
At last the day came. When Mrs. Louella said, "That'll do," oneafternoon, she added, "And that's all. Good-day to you."It was over. We bounded down the sidewalk on a spree of sheerrelief, leaping and howling.
That spring was a good one: the days grew longer and gave us moreplaying time. Carsen's mind was occupied mostly with the vital statisticsof every college football player in the nation. Every night Arielwould read us the sports pages of the newspapers. Alabama might goto the Rose Bowl again this year, judging from its prospects, notone of whose names we could pronounce. Ariel was in the middle ofWindy Seaton's column one evening when the telephone rang.
He answered it, then went to the hat rack in the hall. "I'm goingdown to Mrs. Louella's for a while," he said. "I won't be long."But Ariel stayed away until long past my bedtime. When he returnedhe was carrying a candy box. Ariel sat down in the livingroom andput the box on the floor beside his chair.
"What'd she want?" asked Carsen.
We had not seen Mrs. Louella for over a month. She was never on theporch any more when we passed.
"She's dead, son," said Ariel. "She died a few minutes ago." "Oh," said Carsen. "Well." "Well is right," said Ariel. "She's not suffering any more. Shewas sick for a long time. Son, didn't you know what her fits were?"Carsen shook his head.
"Mrs. Louella was a morphine addict," said Ariel. "She took it as apain-killer for years. The doctor put her on it. She'd have spentthe rest of her life on it and died without so much agony, but she wastoo contrary-" "Sir?" said Carsen.
Ariel said, "Just before your escapade she called me to make herwill. Dr. Reynolds told her she had only a few months left. Herbusiness affairs were in perfect order but she said, 'There's stillone thing out of order.'" "What was that?" Carsen was perplexed.
"She said she was going to leave this world beholden to nothingand nobody. Carsen, when you're sick as she was, it's all right to takeanything to make it easier, but it wasn't all right for her. Shesaid she meant to break herself of it before she died, and that's whatshe did."Carsen said, "You mean that's what her fits were?" "Yes, that's what they were. Most of the time you were reading toher I doubt if she heard a word you said. Her whole mind and body wereconcentrated on that alarm clock. If you hadn't fallen into her hands, i'd have made you go read to her anyway. It may have been somedistraction. There was another reason-" "Did she die free?" asked Carsen.
"As the mountain air," said Ariel. "She was conscious to the last, almost. Conscious," he smiled, "and cantankerous. She stilldisapproved heartily of my doings, and said I'd probably spend therest of my life bailing you out of jail. She had Jessie fix you thisbox-"Ariel reached down and picked up the candy box. He handed it toCarsen.
Carsen opened the box. Inside, surrounded by wads of damp cotton, was awhite, waxy, perfect camellia. It was a Snow-on-the-Mountain.
Carsen's eyes nearly popped out of his head. "Old hell-devil, oldhell-devil!" he screamed, flinging it down. "Why can't she leave mealone?"In a flash Ariel was up and standing over him. Carsen buried his facein Ariel's shirt front. "Sh-h," he said. "I think that was her wayof telling you- everything's all right now, Carsen, everything's allright. You know, she was a great lady." "A lady?" Carsen raised his head. His face was scarlet. "After allthose things she said about you, a lady?" "She was. She had her own views about things, a lot different frommine, maybe… son, I told you that if you hadn't lost your head I'dhave made you go read to her. I wanted you to see something about her-I wanted you to see what real courage is, instead of getting theidea that courage is a man with a gun in his hand. It's when youknow you're licked before you begin but you begin anyway and you seeit through no matter what. You rarely win, but sometimes you do.
Mrs. Louella won, all ninety-eight pounds of her. According to herviews, she died beholden to nothing and nobody. She was the bravestperson I ever knew."Carsen picked up the candy box and threw it in the fire. He picked upthe camellia, and when I went off to bed I saw him fingering thewide petals. Ariel was reading the paper.
PART TWO
Carsen was twelve. He was difficult to live with, inconsistent, moody. His appetite was appalling, and he told me so many times tostop pestering him I consulted Ariel: "Reckon he's got atapeworm?" Ariel said no, Carsen was growing. I must be patient withhim and disturb him as little as possible.
This change in Carsen had come about in a matter of weeks. Mrs.
Louella was not cold in her grave- Carsen had seemed grateful enough formy company when he went to read to her. Overnight, it seemed, Carsenhad acquired an alien set of values and was trying to impose them onme: several times he went so far as to tell me what to do. After onealtercation when Carsen hollered, "It's time you started bein' a girl andacting right!" I burst into tears and fled to Celina.
"Don't you fret too much over Mister Carsen-" she began.
"Mister Carsen?" "Yeah, he's just about Mister Carsen now." "He ain't that old," I said. "All he needs is somebody to beat himup, and I ain't big enough." "Baby," said Celina, "I just can't help it if Mister Carsen'sgrowin' up. He's gonna want to be off to himself a lot now, doin'
whatever boys do, so you just come right on in the kitchen when youfeel lonesome. We'll find lots of things to do in here."The beginning of that summer boded well: Carsen could do as he pleased;Celina would do until Taylor came. She seemed glad to see me when Iappeared in the kitchen, and by watching her I began to think therewas some skill involved in being a girl.
But summer came and Taylor was not there. I received a letter and asnapshot from him. The letter said he had a new father whose picturewas enclosed, and he would have to stay in Meridian because theyplanned to build a fishing boat. His father was a lawyer like Ariel, only much younger. Taylor's new father had a pleasant face, which mademe glad Taylor had captured him, but I was crushed. Taylor concluded bysaying he would love me forever and not to worry, he would come get meand marry me as soon as he got enough money together, so please write.
The fact that I had a permanent fiance was little compensation forhis absence: I had never thought about it, but summer was Taylor bythe fishpool smoking string, Taylor's eyes alive with complicatedplans to make Mallory Gian emerge; summer was the swiftness with whichTaylor would reach up and kiss me when Carsen was not looking, the longingswe sometimes felt each other feel. With him, life was routine; withouthim, life was unbearable. I stayed miserable for two days.
As if that were not enough, the state legislature was called intoemergency session and Ariel left us for two weeks. The Governorwas eager to scrape a few barnacles off the ship of state; therewere sit-down strikes in Birmingham; bread lines in the cities grewlonger, people in the country grew poorer. But these were eventsremote from the world of Carsen and me.
We were surprised one morning to see a cartoon in the  MontgomeryAdvertiser  above the caption, "Maycomb's Chase." It showed Arielbarefooted and in short pants, chained to a desk: he was diligentlywriting on a slate while some frivolous-looking girls yelled,"Yoo-hoo!" at him.
"That's a compliment," explained Carsen. "He spends his time doin'
things that wouldn't get done if nobody did 'em." "Huh?"In addition to Carsen's newly developed characteristics, he hadacquired a maddening air of wisdom.
"Oh, Vance, it's like reorganizing the tax systems of the countiesand things. That kind of thing's pretty dry to most men." "How do you know?" "Oh, go on and leave me alone. I'm readin' the paper."Carsen got his wish. I departed for the kitchen.
While she was shelling peas, Celina suddenly said, "What am Igonna do about you all's church this Sunday?" "Nothing, I reckon. Ariel left us collection."Celina's eyes narrowed and I could tell what was going throughher mind. "Cal," I said, "you know we'll behave. We haven't doneanything in church in years."Celina evidently remembered a rainy Sunday when we were bothfatherless and teacherless. Left to its own devices, the class tiedEunice Ann Simpson to a chair and placed her in the furnace room. Weforgot her, trooped upstairs to church, and were listening quietlyto the sermon when a dreadful banging issued from the radiatorpipes, persisting until someone investigated and brought forthEunice Ann saying she didn't want to play Shadrach any more- Carsen Chasesaid she wouldn't get burnt if she had enough faith, but it was hotdown there.
"Besides, Cal, this isn't the first time Ariel has left us," Iprotested.
"Yeah, but he makes certain your teacher's gonna be there. Ididn't hear him say this time- reckon he forgot it." Celinascratched her head. Suddenly she smiled. "How'd you and Mister Carsenlike to come to church with me tomorrow?" "Really?" "How 'bout it?" grinned Celina.
If Celina had ever bathed me roughly before, it was nothingcompared to her supervision of that Saturday night's routine. She mademe soap all over twice, drew fresh water in the tub for each rinse;she stuck my head in the basin and washed it with Octagon soap andcastile. She had trusted Carsen for years, but that night she invaded hisprivacy and provoked an outburst: "Can't anybody take a bath in thishouse without the whole family lookin'?"Next morning she began earlier than usual, to "go over our clothes."When Celina stayed overnight with us she slept on a folding cotin the kitchen; that morning it was covered with our Sundayhabiliments. She had put so much starch in my dress it came up likea tent when I sat down. She made me wear a petticoat and she wrapped apink sash tightly around my waist. She went over my patent-leathershoes with a cold biscuit until she saw her face in them.
"It's like we were goin' to Mardi Gras," said Carsen. "What's allthis for, Cal?" "I don't want anybody sayin' I don't look after my children," shemuttered. "Mister Carsen, you absolutely can't wear that tie with thatsuit. It's green." "'smatter with that?" "Suit's blue. Can't you tell?" "Hee hee," I howled, "Carsen's color blind."His face flushed angrily, but Celina said, "Now you all quitthat. You're gonna go to First Purchase with smiles on your faces."First Purchase African M.E. Church was in the Quarters outside thesouthern town limits, across the old sawmill tracks. It was an ancientpaint-peeled frame building, the only church in Maycomb with a steepleand bell, called First Purchase because it was paid for from the firstearnings of freed slaves. Negroes worshiped in it on Sundays and whitemen gambled in it on weekdays.
The churchyard was brick-hard clay, as was the cemetery beside it.
If someone died during a dry spell, the body was covered with chunksof ice until rain softened the earth. A few graves in the cemeterywere marked with crumbling tombstones; newer ones were outlined withbrightly colored glass and broken Coca-Cola bottles. Lightning rodsguarding some graves denoted dead who rested uneasily; stumps ofburned-out candles stood at the heads of infant graves. It was a happycemetery.
The warm bittersweet smell of clean Negro welcomed us as weentered the churchyard- Hearts of Love hairdressing mingled withasafoetida, snuff, Hoyt's Cologne, Brown's Mule, peppermint, and lilactalcum.
When they saw Carsen and me with Celina, the men stepped back andtook off their hats; the women crossed their arms at their waists, weekday gestures of respectful attention. They parted and made a smallpathway to the church door for us. Celina walked between Carsen andme, responding to the greetings of her brightly clad neighbors.
"What you up to, Miss Cal?" said a voice behind us.
Celina's hands went to our shoulders and we stopped and lookedaround: standing in the path behind us was a tall Negro woman. Herweight was on one leg; she rested her left elbow in the curve of herhip, pointing at us with upturned palm. She was bullet-headed withstrange almond-shaped eyes, straight nose, and an Indian-bow mouth.
She seemed seven feet high.
I felt Celina's hand dig into my shoulder. "What you want, Lula?"she asked, in tones I had never heard her use. She spoke quietly, contemptuously.
"I wants to know why you bringin' white chillun to nigger church." "They's my comp'ny," said Celina. Again I thought her voicestrange: she was talking like the rest of them.
"Yeah, an' I reckon you's comp'ny at the Chase house durin' theweek."A murmur ran through the crowd. "Don't you fret," Celinawhispered to me, but the roses on her hat trembled indignantly.
When Lula came up the pathway toward us Celina said, "Stopright there, nigger."Lula stopped, but she said, "You ain't got no business bringin'
white chillun here- they got their church, we got our'n. It is ourchurch, ain't it, Miss Cal?"Celina said, "It's the same God, ain't it?"Carsen said, "Let's go home, Cal, they don't want us here-"I agreed: they did not want us here. I sensed, rather than saw, thatwe were being advanced upon. They seemed to be drawing closer to us, but when I looked up at Celina there was amusement in her eyes.
When I looked down the pathway again, Lula was gone. In her placewas a solid mass of colored people.
One of them stepped from the crowd. It was Zeebo, the garbagecollector. "Mister Carsen," he said, "we're mighty glad to have you allhere. Don't pay no 'tention to Lula, she's contentious becauseReverend Sykes threatened to church her. She's a troublemaker from wayback, got fancy ideas an' haughty ways- we're mighty glad to haveyou all."With that, Celina led us to the church door where we were greetedby Reverend Sykes, who led us to the front pew.
First Purchase was unceiled and unpainted within. Along its wallsunlighted kerosene lamps hung on brass brackets; pine benches servedas pews. Behind the rough oak pulpit a faded pink silk bannerproclaimed God Is Love, the church's only decoration except arotogravure print of Hunt's  The Light of the World.  There was nosign of piano, organ, hymn-books, church programs- the familiarecclesiastical impedimenta we saw every Sunday. It was dim inside, with a damp coolness slowly dispelled by the gathering congregation.
At each seat was a cheap cardboard fan bearing a garish Garden ofGethsemane, courtesy Tyndal's Hardware Co. （You-Name-It-We-Sell-It）。
Celina motioned Carsen and me to the end of the row and placedherself between us. She fished in her purse, drew out herhandkerchief, and untied the hard wad of change in its corner. Shegave a dime to me and a dime to Carsen. "We've got ours," he whispered.
"You keep it," Celina said, "you're my company." Carsen's faceshowed brief indecision on the ethics of withholding his own dime, buthis innate courtesy won and he shifted his dime to his pocket. I didlikewise with no qualms.
"Cal," I whispered, "where are the hymn-books?" "We don't have any," she said.
"Well how-?" "Sh-h," she said. Reverend Sykes was standing behind the pulpitstaring the congregation to silence. He was a short, stocky man in ablack suit, black tie, white shirt, and a gold watch-chain thatglinted in the light from the frosted windows.
He said, "Brethren and sisters, we are particularly glad to havecompany with us this morning. Mister and Miss Chase. You all knowtheir father. Before I begin I will read some announcements."Reverend Sykes shuffled some papers, chose one and held it atarm's length. "The Missionary Society meets in the home of SisterAnnette Reeves next Tuesday. Bring your sewing."He read from another paper. "You all know of Brother FrancesBertram's trouble. He has been a faithful member of First Purchasesince he was a boy. The collection taken up today and for the nextthree Sundays will go to Helen- his wife, to help her out at home."I punched Carsen. "That's the Frances Ariel's de-" "Sh-h!"I turned to Celina but was hushed before I opened my mouth.
Subdued, I fixed my attention upon Reverend Sykes, who seemed to bewaiting for me to settle down. "Will the music superintendent leadus in the first hymn," he said.
Zeebo rose from his pew and walked down the center aisle, stoppingin front of us and facing the congregation. He was carrying a batteredhymn-book. He opened it and said, "We'll sing number twoseventy-three."This was too much for me. "How're we gonna sing it if there ain'tany hymn-books?"Celina smiled. "Hush baby," she whispered, "you'll see in aminute."Zeebo cleared his throat and read in a voice like the rumble ofdistant artillery:
"There's a land beyond the river."Miraculously on pitch, a hundred voices sang out Zeebo's words.
The last syllable, held to a husky hum, was followed by Zeebo saying,"That we call the sweet forever."Music again swelled around us; the last note lingered and Zeebomet it with the next line: "And we only reach that shore by faith'sdecree."The congregation hesitated, Zeebo repeated the line carefully, andit was sung. At the chorus Zeebo closed the book, a signal for thecongregation to proceed without his help.
On the dying notes of "Jubilee," Zeebo said, "In that far-offsweet forever, just beyond the shining river."Line for line, voices followed in simple harmony until the hymnended in a melancholy murmur.
I looked at Carsen, who was looking at Zeebo from the corners of hiseyes. I didn't believe it either, but we had both heard it.
Reverend Sykes then called on the Lord to bless the sick and thesuffering, a procedure no different from our church practice, exceptReverend Sykes directed the Deity's attention to several specificcases.
His sermon was a forthright denunciation of sin, an austeredeclaration of the motto on the wall behind him: he warned his flockagainst the evils of heady brews, gambling, and strange women.
Mallorytleggers caused enough trouble in the Quarters, but women wereworse. Again, as I had often met it in my own church, I was confrontedwith the Impurity of Women doctrine that seemed to preoccupy allclergymen.
Carsen and I had heard the same sermon Sunday after Sunday, with onlyone exception. Reverend Sykes used his pulpit more freely to expresshis views on individual lapses from grace: Jim Hardy had been absentfrom church for five Sundays and he wasn't sick; Constance Jackson hadbetter watch her ways- she was in grave danger for quarreling with herneighbors; she had erected the only spite fence in the history ofthe Quarters.
Reverend Sykes closed his sermon. He stood beside a table in frontof the pulpit and requested the morning offering, a proceeding thatwas strange to Carsen and me. One by one, the congregation came forwardand dropped nickels and dimes into a black enameled coffee can. Carsenand I followed suit, and received a soft, "Thank you, thank you," asour dimes clinked.
To our amazement, Reverend Sykes emptied the can onto the tableand raked the coins into his hand. He straightened up and said,"This is not enough, we must have ten dollars."The congregation stirred. "You all know what it's for- Helen can'tleave those children to work while Frances's in jail. If everybody givesone more dime, we'll have it-" Reverend Sykes waved his hand andcalled to someone in the back of the church. "Alec, shut the doors.
Nobody leaves here till we have ten dollars."Celina scratched in her handbag and brought forth a batteredleather coin purse. "Naw Cal," Carsen whispered, when she handed him ashiny quarter, "we can put ours in. Gimme your dime, Vance."The church was becoming stuffy, and it occurred to me thatReverend Sykes intended to sweat the amount due out of his flock. Fanscrackled, feet shuffled, tobacco-chewers were in agony.
Reverend Sykes startled me by saying sternly, "Carlow Richardson, i haven't seen you up this aisle yet."A thin man in khaki pants came up the aisle and deposited a coin.
The congregation murmured approval.
Reverend Sykes then said, "I want all of you with no children tomake a sacrifice and give one more dime apiece. Then we'll have it."Slowly, painfully, the ten dollars was collected. The door wasopened, and the gust of warm air revived us. Zeebo lined  OnJordan's Stormy Banks,  and church was over.
I wanted to stay and explore, but Celina propelled me up theaisle ahead of her. At the church door, while she paused to talkwith Zeebo and his family, Carsen and I chatted with Reverend Sykes. Iwas bursting with questions, but decided I would wait and letCelina answer them.
"We were 'specially glad to have you all here," said Reverend Sykes.
"This church has no better friend than your daddy."My curiosity burst: "Why were you all takin' up collection for FrancesBertram's wife?" "Didn't you hear why?" asked Reverend Sykes. "Helen's got threelittle'uns and she can't go out to work-" "Why can't she take 'em with her, Reverend?" I asked. It wascustomary for field Negroes with tiny children to deposit them inwhatever shade there was while their parents worked- usually thebabies sat in the shade between two rows of cotton. Those unable tosit were strapped papoose-style on their mothers' backs, or resided inextra cotton bags.
Reverend Sykes hesitated. "To tell you the truth, Miss JeanLouise, Helen's finding it hard to get work these days… when it'spicking time, I think Mr. Austin Kristie'll take her." "Why not, Reverend?"Before he could answer, I felt Celina's hand on my shoulder. Atits pressure I said, "We thank you for lettin' us come." Carsen echoedme, and we made our way homeward.
"Cal, I know Frances Bertram's in jail an' he's done somethin' awful, but why won't folks hire Helen?" I asked.
Celina, in her navy voile dress and tub of a hat, walkedbetween Carsen and me. "It's because of what folks say Frances's done," shesaid. "Folks aren't anxious to- to have anything to do with any of hisfamily." "Just what did he do, Cal?"Celina sighed. "Old Mr. Gia Leena accused him of rapin' hisgirl an' had him arrested an' put in jail-" "Mr. Leena?" My memory stirred. "Does he have anything to do withthose Leenas that come every first day of school an' then go home?
Why, Ariel said they were absolute trash- I never heard Ariel talkabout folks the way he talked about the Leenas. He said-" "Yeah, those are the ones." "Well, if everybody in Maycomb knows what kind of folks the Leenasare they'd be glad to hire Helen… what's rape, Cal?" "It's somethin' you'll have to ask Mr. Chase about," she said. "Hecan explain it better than I can. You all hungry? The Reverend tooka long time unwindin' this morning, he's not usually so tedious." "He's just like our preacher," said Carsen, "but why do you all singhymns that way?" "Linin'?" she asked.
"Is that what it is?" "Yeah, it's called linin'. They've done it that way as long as I canremember."Carsen said it looked like they could save the collection money for ayear and get some hymn-books.
Celina laughed. "Wouldn't do any good," she said. "They can'tread." "Can't read?" I asked. "All those folks?" "That's right," Celina nodded. "Can't but about four folks inFirst Purchase read… I'm one of 'em." "Where'd you go to school, Cal?" asked Carsen.
"Nowhere. Let's see now, who taught me my letters? It was MissCoby Ashlie's aunt, old Miss Buford-" "Are you  that  old?" "I'm older than Mr. Chase, even." Celina grinned. "Not sure howmuch, though. We started rememberin' one time, trying to figure outhow old I was- I can remember back just a few years more'n he can, so I'm not much older, when you take off the fact that men can'tremember as well as women." "What's your birthday, Cal?" "I just have it on Christmas, it's easier to remember that way- Idon't have a real birthday." "But Cal," Carsen protested, "you don't look even near as old asAriel." "Colored folks don't show their ages so fast," she said.
"Maybe because they can't read. Cal, did you teach Zeebo?" "Yeah, Mister Carsen. There wasn't a school even when he was a boy. Imade him learn, though."Zeebo was Celina's eldest son. If I had ever thought about it, i would have known that Celina was of mature years- Zeebo hadhalf-grown children- but then I had never thought about it.
"Did you teach him out of a primer, like us?" I asked.
"No, I made him get a page of the Bible every day, and there was abook Miss Buford taught me out of- bet you don't know where I got it,"she said.
We didn't know.
Celina said, "Your Granddaddy Chase gave it to me." "Were you from the Landing?" Carsen asked. "You never told us that." "I certainly am, Mister Carsen. Grew up down there between the BufordPlace and the Landin'. I've spent all my days workin' for theChasees or the Bufords, an' I moved to Maycomb when your daddy andyour mamma married." "What was the book, Cal?" I asked.
"Blackstone's  Commentaries."Carsen was thunderstruck. "You mean you taught Zeebo outa  that?" "Why yes sir, Mister Carsen." Celina timidly put her fingers toher mouth. "They were the only books I had. Your grandaddy said Mr.
Blackstone wrote fine English-" "That's why you don't talk like the rest of 'em," said Carsen.
"The rest of who?" "Rest of the colored folks. Cal, but you talked like they did inchurch…"That Celina led a modest double life never dawned on me. The ideathat she had a separate existence outside our household was a novelone, to say nothing of her having command of two languages.
"Cal," I asked, "why do you talk nigger-talk to the- to your folkswhen you know it's not right?" "Well, in the first place I'm black-" "That doesn't mean you hafta talk that way when you know better,"said Carsen.
Celina tilted her hat and scratched her head, then pressed herhat down carefully over her ears. "It's right hard to say," shesaid. "Suppose you and Vance talked colored-folks' talk at home it'dbe out of place, wouldn't it? Now what if I talked white-folks' talkat church, and with my neighbors? They'd think I was puttin' on airsto beat Moses." "But Cal, you know better," I said.
"It's not necessary to tell all you know. It's not ladylike- inthe second place, folks don't like to have somebody around knowin'
more than they do. It aggravates 'em. You're not gonna change any ofthem by talkin' right, they've got to want to learn themselves, andwhen they don't want to learn there's nothing you can do but keep yourmouth shut or talk their language." "Cal, can I come to see you sometimes?"She looked down at me. "See me, honey? You see me every day." "Out to your house," I said. "Sometimes after work? Ariel canget me." "Any time you want to," she said. "We'd be glad to have you."We were on the sidewalk by the Gian Place.
"Look on the porch yonder," Carsen said.
I looked over to the Gian Place, expecting to see its phantomoccupant sunning himself in the swing. The swing was empty.
"I mean our porch," said Carsen.
I looked down the street. Enarmored, upright, uncompromising, RickIliana was sitting in a rocking chair exactly as if she had satthere every day of her life.
13"Put my bag in the front bedroom, Celina," was the first thingRick Iliana said. "Jean Louise, stop scratching your head," was thesecond thing she said.
Celina picked up Ricky's heavy suitcase and opened the door.
"I'll take it," said Carsen, and took it. I heard the suitcase hit thebedroom floor with a thump. The sound had a dull permanence about it.
"Have you come for a visit, Ricky?" I asked. Rick Iliana's visitsfrom the Landing were rare, and she traveled in state. She owned abright green square Buick and a black chauffeur, both kept in anunhealthy state of tidiness, but today they were nowhere to be seen.
"Didn't your father tell you?" she asked.
Carsen and I shook our heads.
"Probably he forgot. He's not in yet, is he?" "Nome, he doesn't usually get back till late afternoon," said Carsen.
"Well, your father and I decided it was time I came to stay with youfor a while." "For a while" in Maycomb meant anything from three days to thirtyyears. Carsen and I exchanged glances.
"Carsen's growing up now and you are too," she said to me. "Wedecided that it would be best for you to have some feminine influence.
It won't be many years, Jean Louise, before you become interested inclothes and boys-"I could have made several answers to this: Cal's a girl, it would bemany years before I would be interested in boys, I would never beinterested in clothes… but I kept quiet.
"What about Uncle Jimmy?" asked Carsen. "Is he comin', too?" "Oh no, he's staying at the Landing. He'll keep the place going."The moment I said, "Won't you miss him?" I realized that this wasnot a tactful question. Uncle Jimmy present or Uncle Jimmy absent madenot much difference, he never said anything. Rick Iliana ignored myquestion.
I could think of nothing else to say to her. In fact I could neverthink of anything to say to her, and I sat thinking of past painfulconversations between us: How are you, Jean Louise? Fine, thank youma'am, how are you? Very well, thank you, what have you been doingwith yourself? Nothin'. Don't you do anything? Nome. Certainly youhave friends? Yessum. Well what do you all do? Nothin'.
It was plain that Ricky thought me dull in the extreme, because Ionce heard her tell Ariel that I was sluggish.
There was a story behind all this, but I had no desire to extract itfrom her then. Today was Sunday, and Rick Iliana was positivelyirritable on the Lord's Day. I guess it was her Sunday corset. She wasnot fat, but solid, and she chose protective garments that drew up herbosom to giddy heights, pinched in her waist, flared out her rear, andmanaged to suggest that Rick Iliana's was once an hour-glassfigure. From any angle, it was formidable.
The remainder of the afternoon went by in the gentle gloom thatdescends when relatives appear, but was dispelled when we heard acar turn in the driveway. It was Ariel, home from Montgomery. Carsen, forgetting his dignity, ran with me to meet him. Carsen seized hisbriefcase and bag, I jumped into his arms, felt his vague dry kiss andsaid, "'d you bring me a book? 'd you know Ricky's here?"Ariel answered both questions in the affirmative. "How'd youlike for her to come live with us?"I said I would like it very much, which was a lie, but one mustlie under certain circumstances and at all times when one can't doanything about them.
"We felt it was time you children needed- well, it's like this, vance," Ariel said. "Your aunt's doing me a favor as well as youall. I can't stay here all day with you, and the summer's going tobe a hot one." "Yes sir," I said, not understanding a word he said. I had anidea, however, that Rick Iliana's appearance on the scene was notso much Ariel's doing as hers. Ricky had a way of declaring WhatIs Best For The Family, and I suppose her coming to live with us wasin that category.
Maycomb welcomed her. Miss Coby Ashlie baked a Lane cake soloaded with shinny it made me tight; Miss Stephanie Crawford hadlong visits with Rick Iliana, consisting mostly of Miss Stephanieshaking her head and saying, "Uh, uh, uh." Miss Rachel next door hadRicky over for coffee in the afternoons, and Mr. Jovan Gian went sofar as to come up in the front yard and say he was glad to see her.
When she settled in with us and life resumed its daily pace, RickIliana seemed as if she had always lived with us. Her MissionarySociety refreshments added to her reputation as a hostess （she did notpermit Celina to make the delicacies required to sustain theSociety through long reports on Rice Christians）； she joined andbecame Secretary of the Maycomb Amanuensis Club. To all partiespresent and participating in the life of the county, Rick Ilianawas one of the last of her kind: she had river-boat, boarding-schoolmanners; let any moral come along and she would uphold it; she wasborn in the objective case; she was an incurable gossip. When RickIliana went to school, self-doubt could not be found in anytextbook, so she knew not its meaning. She was never bored, andgiven the slightest chance she would exercise her royal prerogative:
she would arrange, advise, caution, and warn.
She never let a chance escape her to point out the shortcomings ofother tribal groups to the greater glory of our own, a habit thatamused Carsen rather than annoyed him: "Ricky better watch how she talks-scratch most folks in Maycomb and they're kin to us."Rick Iliana, in underlining the moral of young Sam Merriweather'ssuicide, said it was caused by a morbid streak in the family. Let asixteen-year-old girl giggle in the choir and Ricky would say, "Itjust goes to show you, all the Penfield women are flighty."Everybody in Maycomb, it seemed, had a Streak: a Drinking Streak, aGambling Streak, a Mean Streak, a Funny Streak.
